pages.headline: Mario's nights with Roo girl
pages.teaser: SOCCER star cheated on model girlfriend by having sex with tart Jennifer Thompson
pages.articlebody:
SOCCER’S Mario Balotelli cheated on his model girlfriend by having sex with Wayne Rooney threesome hooker Jennifer Thompson.

The Manchester City star, 21, bedded Jennifer, 24, even though he once taunted her over her 2010 romp with Man U’s Rooney.

The footie bad boy slept with Jennifer two days before he declared his love for his long-term girlfriend in front of 47,000 fans.

The striker met former escort girl Jennifer five times and had sex with her twice behind the back of gorgeous model Raffaella Fico, The Sun can reveal.

Jennifer became notorious in 2010 when it was revealed Manchester United superstar Wayne Rooney paid her and hooker pal Helen Wood £1,200 for a seedy threesome in a hotel.

Two days after bedding Jennifer, Italian Balotelli lifted his Man City shirt when he scored against Blackburn Rovers to reveal a scrawled message reading “Raffaella Ti Amo” — meaning “Raffaella, I love you”.

Five days after that the goal ace was seen in a strip club. And the following day he met party girl Jennifer again, though they did not have sex on that occasion.

Their relationship was unlikely given Balotelli taunted her about her threesome with Rooney when he spotted her in a restaurant last year. Shocked diners heard him chant “Rooney, Rooney” at her as she walked past tables.

Balotelli finally called time on the fling after revealing he had a regular girlfriend.

A friend of Jennifer said: “It wasn’t just a one-off. Jenny saw Mario five or so times and they had sex twice.

“The first time was after a night out in Manchester and he invited her back to a party at his mansion. A fair bit of champagne was flowing and things moved on from there.

“Jenny had no idea he had a girlfriend. He was acting like a single man. He knew she was the girl who had the threesome with Rooney. But that didn’t put him off at all. He asked her all about it.”

The pal added: “Jenny was stunned Mario was interested in her. The last time they met in the restaurant he had been really nasty to her. But Mario was all smiles and charming. He turned it on and Jenny was flattered.

“Mario is the biggest star in football and he wanted to be with her. Jenny has been burned by her involvement with footballers before but she fell for it.

“He was caring, loving, sensual and made her feel special. But she hasn’t seen him since her birthday last month. One night he told her about Raffaella and that was the end of it.”

Balotelli’s agent Mino Raiola yesterday admitted the player had a “brief involvement” with Jennifer. He called Balotelli “young and impulsive” and claimed he was a target for girls who “chase” footballers.

Mr Raiola added: “Mario prefers to admit what has happened, has refused any means to try to keep the matter silent and will deal with any consequences his actions bring in the way of public attention.”

Rooney had his hotel threesome while his wife Coleen was pregnant. And for a time, it left their marriage on a knife edge.

pages.headline: Navy chopper ace saves 14
pages.teaser: MIKE Henson rescues 14 people in 24 hours
pages.articlebody:
ROYAL Navy legend Mike Henson rescued 14 people in 24 hours — an astonishing repeat of heroism that won him a Sun Millies gong.

The helicopter winchman first plucked to safety nine hikers trapped by a snowstorm on a mountain in Scotland.

Then hours later he was lowered on to a gale-lashed tanker that ran aground on rocks in North Wales and lifted off five crewmen.

Petty Officer Henson, 29, had ALREADY scooped The Sun’s Most Outstanding Sailor award last December for saving 13 crew from a stricken tanker off Oman.

He received his gong from rugby legend Lawrence Dallaglio and singer Myleene Klass.

But a source said last night: “He’s done it again. The man’s a legend.”

The new drama unfolded on Tuesday — Mike’s FIRST day on duty after qualifying for official search and rescue duties.

The previous rescue was as a normal ship’s helicopter crewman.

His Sea King was scrambled from HMS Gannet in Ayrshire, to help the climbers on Ben Macdui, the UK’s second highest mountain.

The crew had just refuelled when they were sent to Llanddulas, near Colwyn Bay, where huge waves were pounding the stuck ship.

During the rescue, the winch cable snapped, stranding Mike and two remaining sailors on deck. An RAF Sea King flew to their rescue.

Modest dad-of-three Mike, from Cumbria, said: “All in all, it was a pretty hard first day on the job.”

pages.subdeck: WE CAN BE LAMPIONS ... Frank Lampard targets Champions League glory
pages.headline: Bring it on Barca
pages.teaser: MIDFIELDER roared ‘Bring on Barcelona’ but Mourinho wrote off Chelsea’s hopes
pages.articlebody:
FRANK LAMPARD last night roared ‘Bring on Barcelona’ — just as Jose Mourinho wrote off Chelsea’s hopes.

The Catalans await Roberto Di Matteo’s Blues in the last four of the Champions League.

The two sides met at the same stage in 2009 when the Londoners lost in controversial fashion.

Lamps, whose first-half penalty helped sink 10-man Benfica, said: “That game is still in our minds but this is completely different year and we need to try to beat them this year.

“Everyone has unfinished business with them.

“You have to respect they are the greatest team in the world — they have been and still are.

“They are going to be favourites because of the way they are playing.

“We know we’ll have to perform at our absolute best to beat them and we believe we can do that.”

But former Stamford Bridge boss Mourinho — now at Real Madrid, who face Bayern Munich in the other semi-final — does not rate his old club’s chances.

The Special One said: “Let me be honest, I don’t think the final will be Real Madrid against Chelsea.

“It can be Bayern, it can be Barcelona, I just don’t think it will be Real Madrid and Chelsea.”

Lampard’s penalty put the London club 2-0 up on aggregate but Javi Garcia’s late effort had the nerves jangling.

Raul Meireles made the tie safe in the last minute but Chelsea’s place in the last four may have come at a cost.

The club fear John Terry has cracked a couple of ribs and the skipper will have a scan this morning.

Interim boss Di Matteo said: “We knew we were facing a difficult game. It proved that way.

“The second goal was missing to kill the game. They still had a chance and knew that.”

pages.subdeck: Fighter ... Sara Payne has been helping victims of paedophiles since her daughter was killed
pages.headline: Sara in plea for blitz on paedos
pages.teaser: MUM of murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne says the problem is spiralling out of control
pages.articlebody:
THE mum of murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne is sickened at how Britain’s paedophile problem is spiralling out of control.

Thousands of sick perverts are going unpunished across the country, according to figures revealed by the NSPCC yesterday.

And campaigner Sara Payne — whose eight-year-old daughter was killed in 2000 by a known paedophile — is horrified at the shocking statistics.

She said: “It has been a really tough couple of years for me, but I will never give up. And this report just goes to show why.

“Britain is overrun by paedophiles and their legally-aided human rights solicitors. It is high time we did something meaningful about the way they get away with it.

“It is our children who will pay the price for these failures.”

The Sun yesterday revealed that the NSPCC had obtained figures showing that there were 23,097 child sex offences in England and Wales last year — or one child being abused every 20 minutes.

But only ten per cent of offences reported led to a person being convicted and sentenced.

Sara, who became the country’s first Victims’ Champion — an independent voice for the victims of crime — in 2009, said she was “sickened” by the NSPCC report.

The 43-year-old — who campaigned to have Sarah’s Law introduced, which allows worried parents to discover whether people in contact with their kids have a criminal record — said: “This week is the first anniversary of the national launch of Sarah’s Law.

“It was set up to help parents protect their children from known paedophiles.

“The latest figures show over 200 children have been protected. I feel an enormous sense of pride in what is happening in my daughter’s name.

“Things like the latest shocking NSPCC report drive me on.

“Not enough is being done for children in peril. They are not given enough support to bring the evil people who do these things to justice. The system completely lets them down.

“To get paedophile victims to come forward, stop calling indecent images of children ‘child porn’. It’s offensive.

“For better conviction rates, give victims a legally-aided solicitor. They need one to help them through the justice system and to fight on their behalf when it lets them down.

“Defendants get one from the moment they are arrested. Victims need one too.

“For better justice and public protection do the only thing that actually works — put paedophiles in jail for longer. Sentences should reflect the real harm done.

“Much, much more needs to be done to help the victims recover.”

After Sarah was murdered, Sara also lost her brother, her mother, then her father. Her marriage broke down and, in 2009, she suffered a devastating stroke which left her partially paralysed.

After such difficult challenges, you may expect her to be the last person to be feeling positive. But Sara — who was awarded the MBE in 2008 for her child protection work — has bounced back and teamed up with fellow campaigner and victim’s advocate Shy Keenan.

Shy, 48, was sexually abused from the age of four and sold to sex fiends by her evil stepfather for just £15. Her abusers were finally jailed in 2002 after a TV exposé.

These two strong women in 2004 formed The Phoenix Chief Advocates to help victims of paedophiles.

For the last decade they have campaigned tirelessly together. And in 2008 both Sara and Shy were awarded the Woman Of The Year gong for their work with victims. The pair have also written a bestselling book, Where Angels Fear.

Now the two women are going into battle once again. They are launching a new website to give victims of paedophiles a place where they can get support and advice safely online.

They want to show victims of abuse there is a life worth living.

Their new free online service, thephoenixpost.com, is aimed at helping both victims of abuse and child protectors.

Sara said: “It is about learning to stand up for yourself but it is also about showing the rest of the world how absolutely amazing all the victims are.”

The site has its own YouTube TV channel, an online radio station and a vibrant social network.

But Shy and Sara need £60,000 in funding to complete the project.

Sara said: “We started building thephoenixpost.com in January using only the free online services available. If we are to make this all it can be, we need to raise sponsorship.

“Our experience has shown that often victims feel they have no one to turn to. This website is a new chapter in mine and Shy’s lives.

“We feel it can do so much good for those who need help. But we really need money to get it running properly and we are calling on Sun readers to help us. They have been fantastic to us in the past and we know they will realise how important thephoenixpost.com is.”

Shy added: “As I well know, child abuse victims often feel stigmatised. As you grow up, you feel it is not something you can tell people. It isn’t something you feel you could ever confide to friends or employers — people just treat you differently when they know. We are hoping to make The Phoenix Post the place that people can go to for the information they want and the support they need to help challenge the misconceptions of victims of paedophile crimes.

“Victims can and do survive, and they thrive so much better when we help them.”

Over the past ten years Shy and Sara have helped countless victims, including Paul, who wrote to thank them for their help.

He said: “My first contact with The Phoenix Chief Advocates was in October 2004. I was one of William Goad’s victims. He received a life sentence for decades of sexual abuse against young boys.

“Shy and Sara acted as advocates for the men who gave evidence against him. Many of us had deeply entrenched mental health issues, some of us used drugs to mask the pain. Our lives were shattered by the legacy he left us to carry. There was no support available in the aftermath of the trial. The Phoenix Chiefs tried in vain to find an organisation that could help.

“All the lads trusted Shy and Sara, which was a very rare thing as many of us had issues surrounding trust. They never lied to us.

“The Phoenix Chiefs advised not to let the anger overwhelm us and to use our Phoenix fire to stand up for ourselves. They informed us of our right to appeal against Goad’s minimum tariff of six years before he could apply for parole. They supported us through the process.”

Paul also told how Shy encouraged him to set up a self-help group for the victims of Goad, who may have abused up to 3,500 boys.

This has grown into Operation Emotion which, along with regular meetings, offers victims the help of counsellors and an art therapist. Help is also available to women and child victims of sex crimes.

Paul said: “I am immensely proud of Operation Emotion’s achievements over the years. But if I never had the Phoenix Chiefs to encourage me, to believe in myself and to educate me, this would probably never have happened.

“You can’t imagine how lonely it is being a child victim of sex crimes. You grow up in silence thinking you’re the only one.

“So when you can share and find common ground with others, that’s priceless. The Phoenix Chiefs taught me that.”

pages.headline: Jessie J's shock at gig stabbing
pages.teaser: STAR reveals shock after man was slashed with bottle at venue where she’d performed
pages.articlebody:
JESSIE J told of her heartache yesterday after a man was stabbed and seriously injured at a nightclub where she performed earlier.

The Price Tag singer, 24, had left the venue — where revellers included Boyzone members, Fazer of N-Dubz and rapper Wretch 32 — before the victim was slashed in the neck with a bottle.

But as he lay critically ill yesterday she tweeted: “My thoughts are with the person seriously injured last night at the BlackBerry bbm party. So sad. I really hope they are ok.”

The Voice judge Jessie, who has stepped up security after being targeted by a stalker and web trolls, had sung on stage at the South London nightspot.

She was rushed out by minders at 11.40pm, narrowly missing the bloody attack, which took place at the venue’s bar.

Witnesses said the incident sparked “carnage” as sickened club-goers dashed for the exits.

One onlooker of the attack, revealed in later editions of The Sun yesterday, said: “There was lots of pushing and shoving then the victim was slashed twice with a bottle. There was blood everywhere.”

Actor Kenny Solomons told how he clasped his hands to the 37-year-old man’s neck in an attempt to stem the blood.

The 25-year-old leapt into action using his first aid training from a new medical drama.

Kenny, who appeared in Sky One’s Dream Team, said: “Blood was pouring from a golf ball-sized hole. I put pressure on to try and stop the flow until paramedics arrived.”

Police took statements from the 1,500 club revellers including Wretch 32, Fazer, and TOWIE trio Mark Wright, Joey Essex and Lauren Goodger.

Boyzone stars Shane Lynch, Keith Duffy and Mikey Graham were visiting the club after a Tuesday night booze-up to comfort band-mate Ronan Keating over his marriage split.

Ronan did not attend the club. Shane, 35, said: “What happened was horrendous.”

Cops said a 25-year-old suspect was arrested on suspicion of assault. He was in custody at a South London police station.

nibs.teaser: ANOTHER Level singer held with pal after ‘hotel attack’
nibs.articlebody:
SINGER Dane Bowers has been arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to rape.

The 32-year-old, who topped the charts with boyband Another Level, was held with a male pal after a woman claimed she was attacked in a hotel room.

Hours earlier Bowers had headlined a DJ set at the trendy Deco Lounge nightclub in Hertford, Herts.

The alleged victim is believed to have been at the club before going to a nearby hotel in the early hours of Saturday. She later contacted police.

Specially-trained detectives took a video statement from the woman in a police “rape suite”. Ex-Celebrity Big Brother contestant Bowers was arrested after attending Hatfield police station on Tuesday by prior appointment.

He was accused of conspiracy to rape, while his 35-year-old friend was quizzed on suspicion of rape.

Both had DNA, mugshots and fingerprints taken before being interviewed. It is understood the men deny the allegations and were bailed until May 14.

Bowers, from Surrey, once dated model Katie Price and hit No1 in 1998 with his band’s single Freak Me. He is separated from wife Chrissy Johnston and had a son Kai, 14, with ex-girlfriend Emma-Jane North. The musician, who also promotes cage-fighting events, was held with six others in 2010 on suspicion of conspiring to supply drugs. He was later cleared of all charges.

Hertfordshire Police said yesterday: “A 32-year-old man from Surrey presented himself at Hatfield police station by prior arrangement on April 3.

“The man has been arrested and is assisting police following an allegation of sexual assault.”

nibs.teaser: A MAN trying to escape from police hijacked a car with a 1 and 2-year-old strapped inside
nibs.articlebody:
A MAN trying to flee cops hijacked a car with two babies strapped inside.

He dragged their mum out of her Ford Focus then sped off with the one-year-old boy and his sister, two, screaming.

The suspect was being chased by police on Tuesday morning following reports of a burglary in Erdington, Birmingham.

Police cars forced him to ditch the Focus a mile away and he was wrestled to the ground by a dozen officers in a “violent struggle”.

The infants — who were in the back seats — were quickly reunited by cops with their relieved mum, who is in her 20s. Sgt Nicholas Barnes said: "Thankfully, neither of them was hurt."

Last night Cedric Brown, 44, was charged with two counts of kidnap — plus robbery and possession of a knife.

Brown, of no fixed address, was due to face Birmingham magistrates today. Two other men arrested nearby - aged 18 and 19 - have been released on police bail pending further inquiries.

nibs.headline: Short in 'mongol' blunder
nibs.teaser: FORMER minister is blasted after describing Down’s syndrome kids as ‘mongols’
nibs.articlebody:
FORMER Cabinet minister Clare Short was blasted last night after describing children with Down’s syndrome as "mongols".

The ex-Labour MP used the outdated and offensive term twice on Radio Four.

She had been discussing Game Change – a film about former US vice-presidential candidate Sarah Palin, whose three-year-old son has the condition.

Ms Short, 66, said on the Front Row show: “I was quite touched by the film.

“We see her having a mongol baby - and when she hugs the mongol children I’m afraid it brought me to tears.” Host Mark Lawson said: “Down’s syndrome is the term she and others prefer.” Ms Short replied: "Yes. Sorry, yes."

Charities were quick to criticise the former International Development Minister. Penny Green, of the Down’s Heart Group, said: "It’s sad she has not picked up on the fact that using such words is offensive and the terminology has changed."

Maggie Heart, of the Education Centre for Children with Down’s syndrome, added: “Mongol is as bad as using the word retard.”

Last year comic Ricky Gervais sparked outrage after saying Britain’s Got Talent star Susan Boyle looked like a "mong".

He eventually apologised.

A CANCER victim swindled £110,000 in benefits to jet off on luxury holidays after she was cured by the NHS.

Grasping Debra Allan, 49, who lied that she could barely walk, was jailed for 18 months yesterday.

In five years the ex hairdresser squandered cash she fiddled on holidays to Dubai, Laos and Thailand. In one year alone she spent FIVE MONTHS in Italy.

Mum-of-three Allan — who got the all-clear after a hysterectomy for cervical cancer in 2003 — claimed she took 15 minutes to walk 30 yards.

She said she needed a mobility scooter, plus help getting out of bed, using the toilet and someone to cook and give her medication.

But holiday snaps showed her on a treadmill and on waterslides in Dubai.

Fraud investigators caught her out walking her dogs, carrying a vacuum cleaner and doing her shopping.

She even belonged to a gym. She said her husband Michael, 49, did not work and was her sole carer. But he was an engineer earning £72,000 a year abroad.

Allan, of Wirral, Merseyside, admitted benefit fraud at Liverpool Crown Court. Judge David Aubrey said: “Your dishonesty was blatant.”

pages.subdeck: Snag ... mid-air refuelling system being tested between the giant Voyager tanker and a Tornado
pages.headline: Fleet can't fuel Brit jets
pages.teaser: HUGE setback for refuelling planes meant for RAF — they don’t work on British jets
pages.byline: By DAVID WILLETTS and MATT WILKINSON
pages.articlebody:
A FLEET of supersize refuelling planes meant for the RAF have hit a huge setback — they don’t work on British jets.

Tests have revealed the giant new Voyager air-to-air tankers are not compatible with RAF Tornados.

The connecting pipes which join aircraft together in flight LEAK when fuel is pumped through them.

Even more embarrassingly the system DOES work when it has been tried on US jets.

It is a massive headache for Defence Secretary Philip Hammond and the MoD, which signed a £10billion deal with makers AirTanker for 14 Voyagers.

The tankers — at 60m long and with a 60m wingspan the largest aircraft in the RAF’s history — can carry 100,000 litres of fuel.

They are meant to pass it on to other planes at 5,000 litres a minute, 125 times the speed of garage forecourt pumps.

But now some inside the MoD are starting to fear the Tornado issue could delay delivery of the entire fleet. Nine of the planes are due to be in service as early as 2014.

If the glitch cannot be fixed within the delivery deadline the MoD may hit AirTanker with a financial penalty.

One source told The Sun that boffins are desperately trying to solve the problem of leaks, adding: “They tested it with RAF Tornados but the refuelling system doesn’t work in mid-air.

“They also tried it with American planes and it did work — it’s a big problem.”

Oxfordshire-based AirTanker was awarded the Air Bus Future Strategic Tanker Aircraft (FSTA) contract by the MoD in 2008.

The deal, a Private Finance Initiative partnership, was branded a “bureaucratic nightmare” by the National Audit Office in 2010 which warned it would run hundreds of millions over budget.

The Voyager is a military version of the Airbus 330 and has a dual role as a troop carrier capable of transporting 400 soldiers.

But last year it emerged Voyagers cannot fly into warzones until their missile defence system is upgraded.

The MoD said: “If industry fails to meet its obligations the MoD will expect to recover any additional costs. Once trials are completed, full RAF air-to-air refuelling training will begin.”

  • FOURTEEN Servicemen died when an RAF Nimrod spy plane caught fire after mid-air refuelling over Afghanistan in 2006. An official report blamed “lamentable” safety failures.

pages.teaser: PLOTTER jailed over faked abduction of daughter in reward scam is released
pages.articlebody:
KAREN Matthews — jailed for eight years for faking her own child’s abduction in a reward scam — is set to walk free from prison today, according to reports.

Her release comes less than three years and three months after she was sentenced for kidnap, false imprisonment and perverting the course of justice.

She was jailed for eight years in January 2009 but had already been in custody for eight months.

Matthews' actions in February 2008 sickened the entire country.

The sinister mum-of-five got oddball Michael Donovan to hide her daughter Shannon, now 13, in a plot to claim £50,000 reward money.

As a 24-day police hunt for Shannon got under way, Donovan, 44, imprisoned her in his home, drugged, and tethered the youngster under a BED.

She was found less than a mile from her home in Dewsbury Moor, West Yorks.

Donovan was the uncle of her mother’s then-boyfriend Craig Meehan.

It later emerged she had been REMOVED from a council at risk register as she was no longer deemed vulnerable.

Matthews, 36, cared so little about her kids she forgot how many she had.

And tests on Shannon’s hair showed up traces of drugs, including sedative temazepam and travel sickness pills, that cops believe Matthews used to sedate her daughter so she didn’t have to waste time caring for her.

Kidnap victim Shannon was placed on a child protection register in 2002 but was taken off in late 2004 after social workers decided the family was “settling down”.

pages.teaser: BOLTON Wanderers star is 'getting better day by day', says manager Owen Coyle
pages.articlebody:
FABRICE Muamba is making an incredible recovery and has taken his first steps, it emerged today.

The Bolton Wanderers midfielder is still in hospital after collapsing with a cardiac arrest on the pitch at Tottenham last month.

But his manager Owen Coyle has revealed he is now able to walk.

He said: “When I went to see him last week, he was able to walk around his room.

“He’s come out the bed and sat in the chair. That was a week ago. And bit by bit the improvements are coming. God willing he gets back to a high standard.”

The 23-year-old former England Under-21 received CPR moments after dropping to the ground in front of shocked fans on March 17.

Medics only managed to get his heart beating independently 78 minutes later and it is still unclear whether he will be able to resume his football career.

Coyle told the Daily Telegraph how medical staff had brought the player’s body temperature down before raising it again so the heart could “kick in of its own accord”.

He added: “That was the critical moment. The concern they had was the oxygen to the brain. But the reaction he has had has eased that worry. He’s going the right way.

“He’s getting better day by day. It’s truly remarkable, given where he’s come from, when his heart stopped for over an hour and a half.

“There was a concern about the lack of oxygen during that period, but where he is now is terrific. He’s still got a long way to go. He’s stable. But he’s still in intensive care.”

Meanwhile Bolton are surging ahead after being inspired by Muamba’s fight for life.

Defender Sam Ricketts says his recovery is driving them forward to escape the clutches of the Premiership’s relegation zone.

Since Muamba’s collapse his team has won all three of their league matches and they are a point clear of the drop zone.

pages.teaser: AGENTS warned of Mumbai-style massacre but would not hand over full facts for 'fear sources would be compromised in Britain's open courts'
pages.articlebody:
AMERICAN spy chiefs refused to share vital information about a planned Mumbai-style massacre on British soil, it was claimed today.

The CIA warned MI6 that al-Qaeda linked militants were planning a gun massacre.

But agency bosses declined to give them the full facts because they feared their sources would be compromised, it was claimed.

The warning came 18 months ago. CIA chiefs were worried Britain’s tradition of open justice would expose their sources in court, the Daily Telegraph claimed.

British spies then launched their own inquiry but still do not know for certain if they have uncovered the full extent of the plot, the paper said.

The Government is considering plans to operate of system of “secret justice” so sensitive evidence can be heard in private.

But Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg appeared to scuttle the idea this week as he told furious Lib Dems it wouldn’t be rushed through Parliament.

In a letter to the National Security Council he that MI5 and MI6 “cannot be allowed to ride roughshod over the principle of open justice”.

Justice Secretary Ken Clarke has called for "common sense" to prevail so lives are not lost.

pages.byline: By GRAEME WILSON, Deputy Political Editor
pages.articlebody:
FAMILIES will be £511 a year worse off under changes to tax and benefits that come in tomorrow, Labour claimed yesterday.

Shadow chancellor Ed Balls described George Osborne’s reforms as a “bombshell”.

But Treasury chiefs defended the measures — insisting millions of families will be up to £330 a year BETTER OFF because of them.

The war of words erupted over figures from the respected Institute for Fiscal Studies, which revealed that hundreds of thousands of families will be hit.

Labour said they show the average family will lose £511.

About 850,000 will suffer from a cut in the income threshold for child tax credit from £40,000 to £26,000.

Another 212,000 could lose up to £3,870 under changes to working tax credits. Couples will have to work 24 hours a week — not 16 — to qualify.

Mr Balls said: “Families on middle and low incomes are facing a tax credit bombshell.These independent figures show that while the Government may be giving with one hand they are taking much more with the other.”

But Treasury minister Chloe Smith dismissed Labour’s claims. She said: “From the start of the tax year on Friday 24million households will be £6.50 a week better off.

“We’re taking millions out of tax altogether by raising the personal allowance, putting up to £126 back in pockets.”

Some were found to have turned to drugs in later life because of work pressures or marriage break-ups.

The drugs boom — which also includes taking LSD or amphetamines — emerged in a study of 3,000 people aged 50 to 65 by medics at King’s College London.

The Sun agrees. Making firms pay more in tax for every person hired means bosses take on fewer workers.

The fed-up business community has washed its hands of union-run Labour.

Employers think that there will be more REAL jobs under the Tories.

Exactly what the country needs to hear.

Blaze heroes

FIREMEN didn’t hesitate when they arrived at a blazing block of high-rise flats.

They plunged straight in — and two tragically lost their lives.

The Sun pays tribute to Hampshire fire heroes James Shears and Alan Bannon.

The brave men and women of our emergency services are very special.

When it comes to the crunch, they lay their lives on the line for us.

We are very lucky. We should be grateful and never forget their sacrifice.

Brave champ

TENNIS ace Martina Navratilova faces another tough challenge.

The legendary champ is diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 53.

Not even a superfit athlete like Martina is safe from a cancer that affects women indiscriminately.

Many Sun readers will have a relative or friend who has been struck down.

Cancer survival rates in Britain have improved over the years. But they lag behind much of Europe and America, where Martina is optimistic about her prospects.

Yes, times are tough. But our next Government must do much more to improve our record on survival rates for breast and other cancers.

Brave Martina, who never gave up on court, will not give up on this fight either.

A BBC interview with a terror suspect is costing the public almost £500,000.

Babar Ahmad, 38, was whisked away from his top-security prison cell to spend SEVEN HOURS filming a controversial chat with journalists.

The interview is expected to last just a few minutes when broadcast on BBC2’s Newsnight tonight.

Prison staff and civil servants had to be taken off normal duties so that Ahmad could be interviewed at Long Lartin prison in Worcestershire last week. A source said: “The whole job was a massive headache and took up most of the day. Ahmad was delighted to be the centre of attention.”

The interview only took place after the Government lost a legal battle. Officials had rejected a BBC request to interview Babar, but the decision was overturned by the High Court after a judicial review that cost taxpayers thousands in legal fees.

The public’s final bill — including staff costs, the court case and BBC costs — is estimated at £500,000.

Ahmad, who was arrested in 2004, is wanted by the US for allegedly plotting to kidnap and murder along with money laundering and aiding terrorists. The former IT worker denies involvement in terrorism and has not been charged with any offence. Ahmad is fighting against extradition to the US, where he faces life in jail if convicted.

The European Court of Human Rights is due to rule on his case next week.

The BBC said: “We went to court because the case raises matters of significant public interest. The judges agreed with our position.”

When Michael tried to defend his achievements, listing his humble background, Lord Sugar hit back: “I don’t care where you come from, I don’t care whether you got a 2.1 at Oxford or Cambridge or you’re a streetwise person.”

pages.subdeck: Rare reaction ... Suzi Ferenth was in a coma for two days
pages.headline: Taking the pill nearly killed me
pages.teaser: SUZI Ferenth was left close to death after a rare allergic reaction to the contraceptive pill
pages.articlebody:
MORE than 100million women worldwide use the contraceptive Pill and, for most, it’s perfectly safe.

But Suzi Ferenth, a marketing executive from Edinburgh, was left close to death after a rare allergic reaction caused her to develop a massive tumour on her liver.

She was in a coma for two days and lost so much blood she nearly died.

Here, the 27-year-old tells LYNSEY HAYWOOD her story.

“THE one thing I’ll always remember about the night I fell ill is the excruciating pain — it was like nothing I’d ever experienced.

It was November 2010 and I’d decided to get an early night but I woke in agony at around midnight with a crippling pain beneath my ribcage.

At first I thought I might be having a severe asthma attack, as I had an extreme burning pain in my lungs, but my inhaler did nothing to lessen my symptoms.

I called my mum, who’s a nurse, and she told me to ring an ambulance.

When the paramedics arrived I could barely walk but they didn’t seem to take me seriously. I told them about the burning sensation and they said I was probably suffering from heartburn and gave me a glass of milk.

It was only when I collapsed that they took me to A&E.

The doctors discovered I was bleeding internally — I had no blood in my veins — and sent me for urgent tests. I couldn’t understand what was happening to me. I was 26 with no previous medical problems.

But I could feel myself slipping in and out of consciousness. Much of that night is a blur but I later found out doctors had discovered three tumours on my liver, one of which had burst causing massive internal bleeding.

Thankfully, the tumours were benign but I later found out that if I hadn’t been admitted to hospital when I was, I could have died from blood loss.

I had several blood transfusions and an emergency operation that night to remove the burst tumour.

Meanwhile, my parents made the 125-mile journey from Aberdeen while I was in surgery. I was in a critical condition and they’ve since told me they were terrified I wouldn’t make it.

I remember waking up in the hospital and being very confused.

I’d been in a coma for two days and I’d been placed on life support while my condition stabilised.

The doctors said the operation had been a success and the burst tumour, which was six inches long, had been removed — as had a third of my liver.

The doctors explained that a person can survive on just 25 per cent of their liver while it regenerates.

My liver was so damaged that it was too dangerous to remove the smaller tumours, which were around two inches long, so I had to wait for them to shrink. I’m amazed I couldn’t feel the tumours but it’s fairly common not to experience any symptoms until they burst and leave you in agony.

But the biggest shock was to come, when the doctors explained that the most likely cause of the tumours (or to use the medical term, hepatic adenomas) was my contraceptive Pill.

I’d been taking a popular brand of the combined Pill for 11 years with no side effects so it was difficult getting my head round the idea my Pill might be to blame.

It turned out the hormones in the Pill, either oestrogen or progesterone, had caused the tumours to develop, a rare reaction which occurs in less than one in a million women.

The odds increase the longer you’ve been taking the Pill but it’s still incredibly rare.

I was obviously one of the unlucky ones. I wasn’t able to take legal action against the manufacturer of my Pill, as it said in the small print this could be a rare reaction, but if I’d known I’d never have taken them.

I now have to steer clear of hormones which means I’ll always have to rely on condoms for contraception as not only can I not take the Pill but I’m unable to use other forms of contraception which contain hormones, such as the coil or the implant.

It also means I might have issues if I ever get pregnant, as pregnancy hormones (which are mimicked by the Pill) are known to have caused the same condition.

I’m young and single at the moment, so it doesn’t affect me yet, but I hate to think about it.

A year on, I’ve made a full recovery and, now that I’m not taking the Pill, the remaining tumours have shrunk.

I still have to have regular check-ups every six months and an MRI scan once a year but as long I stay away from hormones I’ll be ok.

What I do have is an eight-inch scar across my stomach. It’s a constant reminder of what happened to me.

Like many women, I thought the Pill was a “wonder drug”, I thought the worst side effects were a bit of bloating, but I was wrong.

It’s taken a brush with death to make me realise that, for me, it’s just not worth the risk.”

myView



Gabrielle Downey, consultant gynaecologist at BMI Priory Hospital in Birmingham

OESTROGEN can cause benign and cancerous tumours but this is very rare and, despite looking after hundreds of women a year who are on the Pill, I’ve only seen two liver tumours.

Some women will develop jaundice or decreased liver function, but again these are very unusual.

Tumours like Suzi’s are formed when the gland cells develop into cystic structures.

When the blood supply bleeds in, the lining gets thinner and they suddenly burst like a balloon, leading to haemorrhaging. You won’t notice anything unless a tumour causes an obstruction. The condition is also idiosyncratic, which means you don’t know until it happens.

But the contraceptive Pill itself is largely very safe. Taking a combined Pill protects you against some cancers such as ovarian cancer.

There’s a slightly increased risk of cervical cancer, probably because most women on the Pill aren’t using condoms which protect against infection.

One of the main risks associated with the Pill is of clotting or deep vein thrombosis – it’s four in 100,000 for women not taking the Pill and this doubles for those who are taking it. The risk increases if you’re sitting for long periods of time, such as on a flight, so if you’re travelling I’d recommend taking one aspirin the day you fly and one the day after.

These risks also increase if you are overweight or a smoker.

Always discuss with your doctor if you have concerns about your contraceptive Pill.

pages.subdeck: Arms 'n' charms ... gun-totting Jackie Carrizosa
pages.headline: I’m the ‘bad ass chick’ who taught Rihanna to shoot in Battleship
pages.teaser: WE meet ex-US Navy Officer Jackie Carrizosa who inspired Rihanna’s debut movie role
pages.articlebody:
THE real-life inspiration for Rihanna’s debut movie role can today be revealed – and she’s just as disarming as the fiery pop superstar herself.

Jackie Carrizosa is the former US Navy officer behind the singer’s tough sailor character Cora Raikes in the upcoming sci-fi blockbuster Battleship.

The feisty 22-year-old brunette was the only girl playing in the US Navy’s football side when she was spotted by the movie’s director, Peter Berg, and drafted in to help the Umbrella singer sail through her first movie part.

Former gunner’s mate Jackie spent a month living millions of men’s ultimate fantasy — teaching Rihanna how to handle weapons, speak Navy lingo and even play footie like one of the lads.

She said: “We were on set from sunrise to sunset — Rihanna was really tough. She was way better than her stunt double.

“She’s not afraid to get bruised or cut. All the stuff her stunt double would normally do, she was doing herself. I taught her how to handle the weapons. When she had a gun in her hand she couldn’t stop smiling. She loved it.”

And Rihanna herself offered the ultimate praise to her trigger-happy mentor. She said: “My character’s name is Raikes. She’s a weapons officer, she’s not afraid of anything. She loves weapons, she knows them — not only her weapons, but every other weapon on the ship.

“We had this bad ass chick on set, her name is Jackie, she was also in the Navy. I was playing what she does in real life. She was all tattooed up and I just looked at her and I was like, ‘You are Raikes’.

“I watched her and really tried to get in her character. She’s fearless and she’s one of the boys and it’s really fun to explore that.”

The Sun tracked down Jackie to her first workplace since completing a four-year stint in the Navy — at a machine gun range in Las Vegas where she has continued to be surrounded by her beloved guns.

Between firing Uzis at an Osama Bin Laden target, Jackie lifted the lid on her month with Rihanna in Hawaii, where the film was shot.

She said: “I can’t believe she said I was a bad ass — she was a bad ass too. She was shooting a mini gun — an electric machine gun — and I was helping her.

“When it was time to shoot I told her not to be nervous and to have fun with it. When she finished she was grinning from ear to ear and said, ‘I see why you love this stuff’.

“I showed her how to hold the gun so she’d look a little more professional. And there is one scene where she was dragging one of the guys out and I helped her out with how to pick him up.

“There was another part when she was playing soccer. I was teaching her that too. She said she loved my tattoos.”

Jackie revealed how she was spotted by director Peter playing in the military tournament.

She said: “He wanted to take a picture of my T-shirt. It was a picture of a guy screaming into the crowd at a concert and it says, ‘Bring the hate’. It’s from a hardcore punk band called The Hoods.

“I went back to the ship and later I got an email from Mr Berg, saying, ‘I’m the weirdo who took pictures of your shirt.’

“He said, ‘Do you want to work with me on this movie I’m making with Rihanna? If not, it’s cool. You’re still a bad ass. Pete’.

“I’m kind of a workaholic so I don’t watch TV. All I knew about Rihanna was that she was a pop star. I’d never listened to her music — it’s not my kind of thing. I was on deployment and I said I couldn’t help — there was no way, because I was on active duty.

“But he wrote back and he had friends on my ship. A few days later the captain came and asked me if I knew Peter Berg or anything about working on a movie with him. I couldn’t believe it. I was like, ‘Oh man, it’s for real’.”

Once on set in Hawaii, Jackie became more than Rihanna’s naval mentor — the Barbados beauty’s entire part was adapted to be based on the real-life sailor.

Single girl Jackie recalled: “Peter liked the way I was a tomboy and took part in all this male-dominated stuff. He made her character more like me.

“When Rihanna played soccer she was really aggressive, like I am — pushing rival players out of the way. And for the soccer scene they even put her in the Hoods T-shirt that the director first saw me in.”

Jackie told Rihanna about her four years in the Navy as a gunner’s mate. She said: “I was a supervisor and was really mean, very demanding. I’m a perfectionist and I wanted my team to be the same.”

She now works at Machine Guns Vegas, a firing range where she is one of six sexy safety officers who show the venue’s visitors how to fire some of the world’s most dangerous guns.

Rihanna’s own attitude to weapons has come under fire in the past after she wore fashion accessories featuring images of guns.

For her role in Battleship — which opens on April 11 — she even had a temporary tattoo of a pistol on her thigh.

But Jackie defended the controversial right to own guns in America. She also backed gun ranges such as the one where she works.

MGV has been slammed by anti-gun campaigners for luring British tourists with their aggressive marketing promising dangerous weapons and attractive women.

But Jackie said: “A lot of Brits get excited around the guns, especially because we have a lot of hot girls that work here.

“I don’t think I’ve seen a single person walk out of the range not smiling. It should be your right to buy a weapon — but it should come with great responsibility.

“As long as you are safe and following the rules then no one is going to get hurt. It’s when you get complacent and start ignoring the rules that things go wrong.

“It’s like anything. Spoons make people fat, pencils misspell words.”

pages.headline: Golf stars’ partners put soccer WAGS to shame
pages.teaser: GOLF stars’ partners are putting soccer WAGS to shame at The Masters in Augusta
pages.articlebody:
THE Masters golf tournament has started in Augusta.

Hooray! Lots of rather serious-looking men walking around dressed in silly shoes and socks and the sort of collared T-shirts your aunty buys everyone for Christmas.

Not your sort of thing?

Well don’t dismiss it completely, because what we will undoubtedly suffer in the fashion stakes, we will gain in the WAGs department.

Because the world’s leading golfers offer us a rather unique group of partners to look at, dissect and admire.

Hovering delicately on the sidelines at The Masters are a group of WAGs who look alarmingly skin coloured.

That’s right! You read that correctly — the shock news in Augusta is not whether Tiger Woods beats Britain’s leading golfer, Luke Donald, but that the WAGs are NOT the colour of cheesy wotsits.

Unlike their footballing counterparts, the golf WAGs (GWAGs) are not vibrant orange, bikini wearing, sunglasses-addicted shopaholics.

And as they assemble at one of the most beautiful events in sport, there will be some seriously talented sportswomen in the mix.

Take Northern Ireland’s Rory McIlroy.

He’s not just dating a sportswoman, he’s dating the sportswoman to end all sportswomen — Caroline Wozniacki, the uber gorgeous and glamorous Danish tennis player right at the top of her game.

Together they make the super sports partnership known as Wozilroy.

“It’s great that she understands how I feel when I play,” says McIlroy, using words that have never knowingly been spoken by an international footballer. “She understands what I need to achieve and supports me all the way.”

It’s alarming, to say the least, and you may wish to sit down as you read the rest of this.

We’ve become used to WAGs who pride themselves on not understanding the offside rule before staggering off on 9in heels, in tiny lime green hotpants, in search of Bacardi and stupidly expensive champagne.

But this is golf — they do things differently here.

And McIlroy is certainly not alone in his penchant for a sports-loving partner.

American Matt Kuchar’s wife Sybi is an avid tennis player. In fact, the duo have entered tennis tournaments together.

There’s no record of how well they do in their doubles efforts but Kuchar said: “I love the fact that she’s sporty. Life’s more fun with someone who ‘gets you’ and understands what you’re about. I like that we want the same things from life.”

And what is particularly heart-warming is that the support and appreciation is not a one-way street. McIlroy has been seen supporting his girlfriend in tennis tournaments around the world, even going on to court and having a go at the sport himself (the verdict on his tennis? He should stick to golf).

Sergio Garcia is another tennis enthusiast. He is WAG-free, but dated former world No1 tennis player Martina Hingis, supporting her tennis as much as she supported his golf. “We help each other,” he said. “That’s what a partnership is.”

Sadly, someone who won’t be there today is Nick Dougherty, denying us the sight of his golf-mad television presenter wife Diana, who says she lives for golf — just like Victoria Beckham lives for football... not.

American Bubba Watson will be there though, ably supported by wife, Angie — a world-class basketball player whose career was cut short by injury.

Angie is 6ft 4in and a mean golfer. “You wouldn’t argue with her on a golf course,” says Bubba. Nor anywhere else if she’s 6ft 4in tall, I imagine.

For golf enthusiasts, one of the biggest stories at the Augusta National club this year will be how the world’s most famous golfer — Tiger Woods — performs, and how he plays against McIlroy. The more pressing question, for WAG watchers, will be whether Woods is “Wagged up” for the occasion.

He’s been linked with Alyse Lahti Johnson since his marriage disappeared in an explosion of newspaper headlines a few years ago.

He says he’s wary of bringing his new girlfriend into the spotlight and subjecting her to public scrutiny, so the first Major tournament of the season might not be the best place to bring her.

But then again — whenever he’s seen with her, there’ll be vast public interest, so why not in the beautiful surroundings of Augusta? Another WAG to look out for is former international gymnast Kate Rose, married to Justin Rose.

She persuaded her husband to work through some of her old gymnastics moves when he had a bad back and managed to alleviate all his pain.

“I’m a sportswoman, I understood instinctively what was needed,” she said. Sadly, there are no pictures of him doing splits on the beam in a leotard.

“Going out with a former sportswoman has its advantages,” said Justin. So it seems, judging by the number of leading golfers who do.



Beauties giving game glamour

Left: Stunning birdie Kate Rose is married to England ace Justin. A former international gymnast, she quit her job as a PA to travel the tour circuit with her husband.

Right: Laurae Westwood met Lee at the 1995 Scottish Open through her brother Andrew Coltart, another pro golfer at the time. They married in 1999.

Left: Amy Mickelson’s husband Phil is one of the most famous golfers of all time. Diagnosed with breast cancer in 2009, Amy is famous for her charity work.

Right: Chicago-born Diane Donald met Brit Luke at university in Illinois while studying fine art. They married in 2007 and have two daughters.

Left: Caroline Harrington and hubby Padraig, 40, have been together since their teens. They met when Caroline’s father took her to see a junior golf match.

Right: Sonya Toms has been married to David, winner of 13 PGA Tour titles, for ten years. She lists her hobbies on his official website as “exercise and cooking”.

pages.teaser: UK WOMEN also include the bra, disposable nappies and mascara in their top ten list
pages.articlebody:
UK WOMEN have picked their favourite inventions of the last century – and practicality is the key.

Leisure breakthroughs such as the internet and TV were snubbed in favour of the Pill, the bra, the washing machine and disposable nappies.

Tampons, pregnancy tests, jeans and mascara also made it into the top ten for the 2,000 British females quizzed.

Leading the poll was that little oestrogen creation The Pill, with 65 per cent of women heralding the control they now have over starting a family compared to previous generations.

The bra was the second most influential product, with many hailing it as “revolutionary”.

A surprise entry was the washing machine — that was most popular with women over 45.

But major developments of the digital age, including the internet, didn’t feature at all.

The survey, by pregnancy test firm Clearblue Plus, asked women to pick the inventions that had been most valuable to them.

Psychotherapist Christine Webber said: “The list highlights the differences between the generations. For the older generation items such as the washing machine really did make a huge difference to their lives.

“For the younger generation, products and designs such as the bra often enhance what they’ve already got.”

Christine added: “The Pill is also important because it gave women the freedom to choose when to have children and how many to have.

“It gave women a confidence we’d never had before.”

Barmaid Clare Hughes, from Hamble, Hants, said: “I agree with the findings, bras are one of the best inventions.

“In the past they were practical, now they’re more fashionable.

“When I’m wearing a nice bra it gives me a boost and makes my clothes look nicer. I’d never buy a cheap one”.

The 33-year-old added: “The washing machine is a revolutionary invention too.

“I don’t know how women coped without them.”

Amy Jenkins, of Clearblue Plus, said: “It’s interesting to see that good design can have such a positive impact on women’s day-to-day lives.”

Top 10 inventions

1 The contraceptive pill

2 The bra

3 The washing machine

4 Tampons

5 Pregnancy tests

6 Disposable nappies

7 Mascara

8 Jeans

9 Fresh prepared meals

10 Contact lenses

pages.headline: Why dying men like my grandad have right to live life without pain
pages.teaser: SOCCER ace, whose relative has disease, says we should fight to make the pill available
pages.articlebody:
A DAILY pill that could extend the lives of men with prostate cancer has been rejected for use on the NHS for being too pricey.

The ruling by health watchdog NICE has angered charities.

They claim that the decision is a “bitter blow” to thousands of men and their families, and campaigners are now fighting to overturn the ban.

Abiraterone usually costs £3,000 for a month’s supply but has been offered to the NHS at a reduced rate.

To raise awareness of the disease, ex-England footballer Les Ferdinand, 45, whose grandfather had the disease, tells LYNSEY HAYWOOD why we should fight to make the drug available to all.

We also talk to two men whose lives have improved dramatically thanks to taking this so-called wonder drug.



Ron McCoo, 59



GREAT-GRANDAD Ron was diagnosed with prostate cancer two years ago.

The retired publican – married to Terri and with three daughters, four grandchildren and a great-grandchild – went to the doctors in January 2010, ten weeks after noticing blood in his urine.

Tests on Ron, from Pilling, near Blackpool, showed the cancer had already spread to his bones.

“I’ve taken all sorts of treatments including Zoladex, Taxotere and Cabazitaxel, but all of them stopped working after a while so I started Abiraterone in November. I noticed an immediate difference in my health.

It gave me more strength. I wasn’t as tired and I actually didn’t feel ill. I didn’t seem to get any side effects.

Now I no longer need liquid morphine, which I previously used to cope with the pain.

My wife Terri has also noticed a change in me — we can sit, talk and go out for walks which I couldn’t do before because I would get out of breath.

I’ve got another three months’ supply of the drug and feel extremely lucky.

I know that a lot of other people can’t get Abiraterone. If you can’t afford to pay for it, you just go and die. For me it’s wrong. Their reasoning is for the extra four months you might get it’s not worth it but for me and my family it’s worth more.

I was able to enjoy my great-granddaughter’s first Christmas — something I didn’t think would have been possible before — and I hope we will all be together for her first birthday too.

I’m obviously on the last bit of my treatment, really.

I’ve worked all my life. People with prostate cancer obviously aren’t youngsters and probably worked all their lives as well.

I thought when I started work many years ago that you paid into the system.

I never thought I’d ever see a situation where there was treatment that would be good for me that I couldn’t have.”



Bob Bonthrone, 75



RETIRED finance manager Bob, married to Margaret, 77, learned he had prostate cancer in 2003.

Bob, from Stirlingshire, Scotland, has tried all other available treatments and was devastated when he was turned down for Abiraterone.

It would cost the NHS more than £35,000 for a year’s supply.

“I don’t believe you can put a price on life. I’m astonished that the drug has been turned down and Margaret is devastated. After the announcement, the look on her face said it all.

I’m going through more chemotherapy at the moment but what do I have to look forward to after that? I can’t see why a very effective drug that was developed in the UK can’t be used to help the people of the UK. It doesn’t seem excessively expensive. It has helped some men live for another four years.

My wife and I had so much to look forward to. We were planning on exploring the world. This was going to be our time to enjoy life. It was a shock when I was told that it had actually spread to my pelvis and lymph nodes. But I was determined to get through it.

I started hormone therapy treatment which helped me to get my life back a bit. But by the end of 2008, the pain had returned. The therapy was no longer working and the cancer had spread to other parts of my body.

I had chemotherapy and I took part in a clinical trial of Cabazitaxel, which helped slow the progress of the cancer.

Margaret and I celebrated our golden wedding anniversary in June 2009 with our two children and four grandchildren.

It was a really special party. We had a collection for charity and thanked the NHS for all the excellent treatment I’d had. But now the NHS won’t fund Abiraterone. We really need this drug. It doesn’t seem very expensive when you compare it with the money being paid out to help women who were fitted with PIP breast implants and now need them taken out.

The NHS even pay for people to have tattoos removed. Why do people with prostate cancer come last on the list?”

myView



By OWEN SHARP, CEO of The Prostate Cancer Charity

ABIRATERONE allows men dying of prostate cancer to live a longer and better life.

This pill, developed by British scientists, is one of the biggest breakthroughs in the treatment of the disease in years.

It is appalling to think the men who need it most risk being told they can’t have it due to the cost.

The NHS may be bogged down with financial woes but the fact remains that this drug can increase the amount of time a man with prostate cancer has left to live by an average of about four months.

Abiraterone also reduces pain with very few side effects, giving men the best possible opportunity to enjoy their last few months.

Sadly, while NICE and the drugs company are quibbling about cost, men are dying.

An extra four months of life could give a man the time to walk his daughter down the aisle, see the birth of a grandchild or just spend special time with friends and family.

At least a third of the 10,000 men who will die from prostate cancer this year would have more time if this drug was available to them.

Undoubtedly NICE has some hard decisions to make – but isn’t it time that we all put the patients first?

pages.articlebody:
WITH his mullet and unsporty physique, Keith Lemon looks an unlikely Olympics fan.

But the comic, whose ITV1 show LemonAid starts on Saturday, is helping sponsors Adidas to promote London 2012 and has met Team GB athletes, including diver Tom Daley.

Here, he tells why he’s behind the Games.

I DIDN’T know much about the Olympics before, just that there’s a couple of circles in their logo and that Paul McCartney’s daughter Stella designed the suits.

But Adidas have signed me up to meet all the Olympians as part of their Take The Stage campaign. I represent the normal man — although I’m obviously better looking.

A lot of the athletes took a shine to me. They’re so stressed out with training all the time, they liked having a bit of Keith relief.

They’re all ripped these people. You should see their legs — they look like they’re made of potatoes all Sellotaped together.

I don’t really play any sport. I do three hours a day on Swingball and that’s it.

I played tennis star Andy Murray at Swingball and you’d think he would be good, wouldn’t you? He was proper junk, it was obliteration-nil.

Tom Daley has become a close friend and I go swimming and diving with him every Sunday morning. He’s got webbed feet and hands, you know.

If he sees a pond with ducks, he’ll dive in it. It’s an illness for him. He’s got to keep away from water like a Gremlin.

Then there was cyclist Circus Hoy — I didn’t know he was really called Sir Chris — apparently he’s a big fan of Celebrity Juice so we got on like a house that is on fire.

I met cyclist Victoria Pendlekiltontonton, who was quite attractive. One cyclist — who I won’t name — told me they get cheap thrills the faster they go on the bikes.

Athlete Jessica Ennis is all right too, and she’s from my neck of the woods.

Louis Smith is a gymnast who changes his hair every hour. He loves his singing.

He was doing Me And Mrs Jones and I was singing We Don’t Have To Take Our Clothes Off — I see that song as my anthem.

Phillips Idowu can jump the length of a bendy bus.

Why would you walk anywhere? You’d just jump, wouldn’t you?

I didn’t used to like sport. It was football that put me off.

I didn’t like the noise of the crowd.

But I love sport now, me. I love it more than sex.

I’d rather run round the block a couple of times than get jiggy with a lass now.

pages.headline: Would you be pals with an ex?
pages.teaser: AS celebrities like Kelly and Angelina count exes amongst their pals, two women share their very different experiences
pages.articlebody:
WHEN relationships come to an end, most couples part company for good.

But an increasing number of celebrities are now choosing to stay friends with their ex.

Last month, Angelina Jolie wrote the foreword to former hubby Billy Bob Thornton’s book and the two Hollywood stars have remained close.

Model Kelly Brook has stayed in touch with previous boyfriends, rugby ace Danny Cipriani and film star Jason Statham. And actress Courteney Cox still calls former husband David Arquette her “favourite person in the world”. But while these celebs insist being friends with a former lover is healthy, can it work for us mere mortals?

Here, JENNY FRANCIS meets two women with very different views about staying bosom buddies with the ex- lover.

YES, says Lucy O'Connor, 22

WAITRESS Lucy sees her former boyfriend Dom Mitchison, 26, a music student at least once a week. She has now been with Dave Norman, 28, a tiler, for 18 months and says she wouldn’t be happy in any relationship where she is not allowed to see her ex. They are all from Bristol. Lucy says:

“I met Dom in September 2008. We were both students and I fell for him because he was so easy to talk to.

We became great friends first, then evolved into boyfriend and girlfriend.

We moved in together after a year and all was going well until our mutual friend blurted out she had slept with Dom.

I was utterly crushed and my trust of Dom evaporated.

Despite my anger at him breaking us up, Dom and I would bump into each other at university, we had the same mutual friends and I found it impossible to ignore him.

Gradually we became friends again.

We shared so much together in such an exciting period of our lives and that bond couldn’t be broken.

We talk about everything together and he’s a great listener.

But I’d never trust him as a boyfriend again.

I met Dave a year after splitting from Dom and we hit it off.

Dave knows all about what happened between me and Dom. At first he couldn’t understand why I’d want to be friends with him.

But he soon came to understand how supportive Dom had been as a friend — and still is.

So far it’s working out nicely.

The boys get on fine when we meet up together but I’m not sure if they would be friends in their own right.

Dom and I meet up for coffees or early-evening drinks at least once a week.

I don’t discuss relationship problems with him though, I have girlfriends for that.

I feel lucky that I have a boyfriend who understands. If he didn’t, things could get complicated.”

Boyfriend Dave says: “I’m cool with Lucy’s friendship with Dom.

“Dom and I are completely different — I wouldn’t go out drinking with him.

“But he’s funny and I have to respect him because Lucy does.”

Ex Dom says: “To throw away the bond Lucy and I formed would be impossible.

“I know I screwed up but it was completely out of character and I’m very lucky to still have Lucy as a friend.

“I’ve got friends who can’t be friends with their exes so I see myself as fortunate to have Lucy in my life still.

“I really think we’ll be in touch for many years.”

NO, says Suzanne Parker, 36

SUZANNE, who runs a menswear shop in Ormskirk, Lancs, was given an ultimatum: Stay friends with her ex and lose her boyfriend. She says:

“I’d known my ex, Martin, since I was five and we’d always been good friends.

Three years ago we began dating, which turned out to be a big mistake.

What was a friendship soon turned into bickering.

After five months we realised we weren’t suited to one another and split.

At first it was a bit strange between us but once we got over the awkwardness of knowing we’d slept together, we fell back into being friends.

Two months after we split I began dating Adam, who I met through Facebook.

Adam was lovely and we seemed made for each other.

I told Martin about Adam from the start.

He was very excited that I was starting to see someone new.

The two of them met about a month after Adam and I started dating.

They got on like a house on fire and we would often hang out together.

Despite seeing how well they got on, I decided not to tell Adam that Martin and I had been an item.

But two years into our relationship, I was chatting with Adam about my past and casually mentioned I’d dated Martin.

As I told him I could see him become tense and within minutes he was furious.

I tried to convince him nothing would ever go on between us, but he wouldn’t have it.

He gave me an ultimatum — either stop talking to Martin or our relationship was over.

I couldn’t believe it. I was hurt and shocked by his reaction. I told him he couldn’t control me and my friendships.

But he remained adamant it was Martin or him.

I was torn.

I didn’t want to sacrifice a friendship over somebody’s jealousy, but I’d really fallen for Adam and didn’t want to throw away what we had.

For the next month I carried on phoning Martin and each time Adam found out he went ballistic. We had the most awful rows.

Eventually Adam moved out.

I really missed him and phoned to ask him to come home, but he told me that he only would if I stopped talking to my ex, Martin.

I didn’t want to choose.

I was terribly upset that it ended the way it did, but maybe this proves it wasn’t meant to be between us.”

Security worker Adam Smith, 32, says: “I didn’t like the idea of ex-boyfriends being in the background — it felt like an intrusion.

“Suzanne wouldn’t have it though and it was stressing me out so I left.

“It’s over now and it’s all because she wanted to stay friends with her ex.”

Martin Hollenby, 33, a woodworker, says: “It’s sad what happened, but I don’t see why Suzie and I couldn’t be friends.

“There was nothing going on between us. If Adam couldn’t accept that then it’s his problem.

“I thought he was all right — it seems I was wrong.”

pages.articlebody:
ACTRESS Lily Collins has finally emerged from the shadow of rock star dad Phil – and it’s all thanks to Snow White.

The 23-year-old former model is really getting noticed as the fairytale heroine playing opposite Julia Roberts as the Queen in new comedy fantasy film Mirror Mirror.

She was also the romantic lead to Twilight star Taylor Lautner in the 2011 thriller Abduction and has now signed to turn a hit young adult novel called The Mortal Instruments into a movie.

It is yet to be seen whether those projects put her in the same fame league as Dad, who has sold more than 250 million records. But Lily is certainly more youthful and current.

Speaking exclusively to The Sun, she says: “Someone told me they were listening to the radio and they were playing classic hits. At the end the DJ came on and said, ‘For all of you who don’t know, that was Phil Collins — Lily Collins’s dad’.

“I thought that was the weirdest thing, just so bizarre. Even my dad has said to me, ‘You know, I am known as your dad now’.

“But he is extremely proud and couldn’t be happier. He came to the premiere the other day and we were just like a huge family. It was so lovely to have Mum and Dad there.

“It is a weird shift. I am doing what I am now because I am doing it — I never wanted to give anybody the ability to say I am doing something because of family.”

Understandably, Lily is worried people will think having a famous father opened doors for her in the movie industry, giving her an unfair advantage. But there are plenty of sons and daughters of rock stars who have tried and failed to make it in Hollywood.

Phil, 61, who was an actor before he became a rock star with Genesis, has commented about how difficult Lily’s family background has made it for her. He once said: “She’s always got this thing hanging around her neck — she’s Phil Collins’s daughter.”

Lily thinks Dad was just defending her and says: “He is probably just referencing what everyone assumes — that having the last name gives me an opportunity and protecting me from that.”

Whether being Phil’s daughter has helped or hindered, Lily certainly didn’t get her stunning looks from Dad. For those remarkable eyes she has mum Jill Tavelman to thank.

Lily says: “I have seen that more and more. I am seeing characteristics, things that I do that are very her. And I look at photos sometimes and see her smile and her laugh. More and more people are saying that now — and I love it.”

Jill was Phil’s second wife. They married in 1984 and divorced 12 years later. After the break-up, Lily, then seven, went to live with her mother in Los Angeles.

The split was said to be acrimonious, with Phil paying out £17million and finishing the relationship by fax. But now it seems they are friendly again.

Lily, whose birthday was on March 18, says: “I celebrated my 23rd with my mum and dad, who were both here in LA the day after the premiere. We had a very relaxed, quiet day together.”

Although she mainly grew up in the States, Surrey-born Lily has fond memories of an English childhood spent in the company of some of the UK’s biggest stars — including Elton John, who used to babysit her.

She says: “He is definitely a close family friend. I consider myself very European and more British at heart.

“I am not your beachy Californian girl. I enjoy the cold. Whenever I come back to England I automatically relax and feel at home.”

Lily reckons spending her early years in England helped to prepare her for the Snow White role.

She says: “I grew up in England in the countryside in basically farmland and forests.

“I used to run around pretending. I was read fairytales before bedtime and I was totally the young girl who loved fairytale princesses.

“The idea of playing one never crossed my mind and when it happened, at first I thought it was a mistake. But it was an absolute honour and I was so excited to do it that the importance of playing this iconic role didn’t truly hit home until I finished shooting, so I didn’t get to be nervous about it.”

She adds: “To play a character that is the fairest of them all is even hard for me to say — it is the most bizarre concept to me.

“In our story Snow White never once looks in the mirror, so she is unaware of the beauty everyone is talking about. She doesn’t know what effect it has on people.”

And Lily too is confused by the effect she is having on people, with fan sites dedicated to her already springing up.

She says: “It still shocks me that people are interested in me.

“But I can still go about everyday life, go to the market and that kind of thing, without being followed.”

Lily’s first acting role came at the tender age of TWO on BBC television comedy drama Growing Pains.

Before her adult acting career she worked as a journalist for American youth channel Nickleodeon and for British teen magazines such as Elle Girl. She admits it was a way to get experience in front of the camera and a job to do as she waited for her big chance in Hollywood.

The break came when she played the daughter of Sandra Bullock’s character in the Oscar-nominated 2009 film The Blind Side. After that success she decided to concentrate on acting.

Talking about her time as a reporter, she says: “I was always pursuing acting at the same time. I was just auditioning but being told no and so I kept practising. At the same time I wanted to be doing something else. Then I was finally told yes on The Blind Side and there came a point when I had to decide whether the audience could believe me as the character when I was also on television as me.”

Dad Phil started acting young, having gone to drama school at 14 and appearing as the Artful Dodger in a London production of Oliver!

Lily says: “I have always loved dressing up. I was also supported by my family. Me and my dad obviously share a love of acting.”

And they are far from being the only star dad-and-daughter acting team — as our picture gallery, below left, shows.

This new version of Snow White portrays the princess as a strong young woman who is as brave as her prince.

Lily says: “I wanted to play her as a young girl that other young girls could relate to.

“I got to do all these things I have never done before, like fencing and running round in ball gowns and corsets in forests.”

For Lily, there is a similarity between herself and this modern princess. She is not the type of girl who simply lives off her parent’s fame but wants to make her own way in the world.

She says: “She’s a feisty, passionate young woman. I’d definitely say that when I set my mind on something, I really go for it.”
