pages.subdeck: Agony ... Patricia Brady is struggling to cope following the death of her daughter
pages.headline: Evil lover left my girl to die
pages.teaser: WHEN Arshad crashed his car with Emily Brady inside, he told Firefighters it was empty
pages.articlebody:
THE amateur portrait of smiling Emily Brady sits in a frame made of matchsticks.

It is a sickening reminder of Emily’s horrific death in a car crash, sent by her former boyfriend Waqas Arshad from jail.

Emily was 17 when Arshad left her to burn in his blazing car after he ploughed into a tree. Twice Arshad, then 24, was asked by firefighters if anyone else was in the vehicle. Twice he said no. Arshad was sentenced to six years for causing death by careless driving while over the alcohol limit and while uninsured.

From prison he sent two portraits of Emily to her mum Patricia, yet he refused to see her to explain what happened.

Here, Patricia, 51, talks to NIKKI WATKINS about her agony at being denied the right to ask him why he left her daughter to die.

FOR Patricia, every day has been a living hell since losing her daughter.

She says: “Being told Emily had died was too much to comprehend. Emily was caring, full of life and my best friend. To lose her so violently is unimaginable. Losing a child in such an awful way changes you. I will never again be the person I was.”

Patricia’s agony has been heightened by Arshad’s seemingly callous behaviour towards her family. The hospital nurse, said: “Arshad sending the portrait was disgusting. He didn’t ask the prison authorities, who would have asked me if I wanted to receive anything.

“He passed it to a mate to deliver and took that choice away from me. Later, I heard he had applied for early release and I knew I had to ask him questions.

“He refused to see me. But he had no qualms about sending me a portrait of my daughter framed by matchsticks after she burned to death.”

Patricia last saw college student Emily, who was studying to be an accountant, when she waved her off to her part-time job on November 1, 2008.

The mum — who lives in Dunstable, Beds, with lorry driver husband Tom, 49, and student son Jordan, 19 — says: “Emily had a supermarket job to help fund her studies. She headed out after work with friends. Near her curfew she sent a text to her brother Jordan, then 16, telling him she would be home soon.

“Although we were a close family we hadn’t talked much about Arshad, her boyfriend of six months. I saw his car when he dropped her off but that was it. Every time I brought him up Emily would get embarrassed.”

Confident her daughter was on her way home that terrible night, Patricia went to bed. She says: “At 5am the phone rang. Seeing my daughter’s bedroom was empty I started to panic. When Emily’s name came up on the phone screen I relaxed but it wasn’t her voice.

“A man told me he was Arshad’s brother and that there had been an accident and Emily was missing. He asked if she was with me. A police officer came on the line and said he would call back when there was more news.

“I tried to comfort myself with the thought that if Emily was seriously injured, the hospital would have been in touch.

“An hour later I opened the front door to the officer and heard the words, ‘I’m sorry’. I just knew and broke down.”

The officer explained there had been a crash in the early hours. Emily had died.

Patricia would learn later that Emily’s phone had been retrieved by Arshad as he escaped from the burning wreck.

Reeling in shock, Patricia asked to see her daughter’s body. She says: “It was then they told me I couldn’t identify her body. The car had caught fire and there was none.

“Emily had never hurt anyone, why had this happened to us? She was so innocent, she didn’t deserve to die like this. Clinging to the bannister for support, I climbed upstairs to wake Jordan. The agony on his face will stay with me for ever. It was the worst moment of my life.”

The family, who are Catholics, were devastated not to be able to give Emily a traditional funeral service. Her coffin contained a body bag with just a few charred remains.

Patricia says: “After the funeral, attended by more than 1,000 of her friends, my grief worsened. Overnight I went from being a tough, working mother to lying on the sofa just about able to breathe.

“I was haunted by images of her trapped, screaming for help.”

Shortly after the funeral, Patricia was told Arshad had been arrested but she was too consumed with grief to ask why.

Weeks later she bumped into him while visiting Emily’s grave. Patricia says: “We cried together, I hugged him and he kept saying he couldn’t remember anything.”

But, in May 2009, Arshad appeared at Luton Crown Court and admitted causing death by careless driving while over the drink drive limit and causing death by driving while uninsured.

The court heard he and Emily had been for a night out. Driving her home he lost control of the car, crashed into a tree and skidded into a field where the car caught fire. Patricia says: “What came next left me and my family stunned.

“The court heard Arshad freed himself from the car but left Emily trapped inside. When witnesses called for emergency services, he didn’t even tell them she was in the car.

“He was asked by a paramedic and a firefighter if there was anyone in the car. To both he said no.

“Firemen later realised Emily was in the car but by then it was too late. She had been injured during the accident but that hadn’t killed her. She had burned to death.”

Arshad maintained he could not remember what happened. He was sentenced to six years and banned from driving for eight. Patricia says: “I was disgusted one human could allow that to happen to another.

“He’d had time to get Emily’s mobile phone but claimed he was in too much of a state of shock to remember she was in the car. I was left with no doubt that had he told someone she was in there, she might still be alive.

“Emily’s death was utterly degrading. The anger and grief made me have suicidal thoughts.”

Then, when Patricia thought things couldn’t get any worse, the story took another sick twist in March 2010.

Patricia says: “Jordan had answered the door and was handed a parcel from Arshad. I gasped in shock. It was a sketch and a photo of Emily decorated with a clock. Both were framed with matchsticks.

“To make frames out of matchsticks when he had let my daughter burn to death seemed hugely insensitive. I couldn’t look at them but I couldn’t just throw them in the bin because they were pictures of Emily. I had to put them in the loft. It was terrible.

“Had he not considered asking me through the proper channels if I wanted to receive his gifts?

“It may be possible that he had not connected matchsticks with leaving his girlfriend to burn to death but perhaps that is being too kind.”

Last year Patricia was told Arshad had applied for early release. She says: “I knew that to be able to move forward I needed to see him face to face. I asked if I could visit him in jail but he refused to see me.

“He is such a coward. I hope he will change his mind before he is released, which I fear could be as early as this year. I’ve read books on grief, looking for advice, and one day I plan to write my own book to help others grieving in horrific circumstances.

“But in the meantime I hope publishing the pictures of the wreckage in which my daughter died will help save another life by stopping others from getting in a car with a drunk driver.

“Emily would have liked that.”

  • Patricia is donating her fee for this article to Sisters Of St Clare Convent in Luton.

pages.articlebody:
WORKING for an insurance company must be a barrel of laughs.

After the Sun revealed how a startled peacock clawed a car after seeing its reflection in the paintwork, here we bring you more mad cases.

From the bloke whose mother-in-law drove him over the edge to the turkey that took flight from the oven and a driver in the wrong gear, here Kate Jackson rounds up the best odd claims from Admiral, Churchill, Direct Line and Co-Operative.

CLAIMING on their home insurance, one person wrote: “The turkey was in the oven. I opened the door, armed with a baster and oven gloves, but the turkey was heavier than I expected and it flew out of the oven on to the floor! Luckily I had just hoovered so I was able to put it back and finish cooking it. We had a lovely meal, but the carpet was ruined.”

One driver claimed for a damaged car bonnet after it was hit by a tossed boot from a welly wang competition.

Another driver insisted: “I had been driving my car for 40 years when I fell asleep at the wheel.”

And Santa would not have been pleased with this careless kid: “I gave my son £400 for Christmas, who then accidentally threw it out with the rubbish.”

Any insurer would have difficulty tracking down this driver. The claimant said: “An invisible car came out of nowhere, struck my vehicle and then vanished.”

Another motorist was so busy trying to swat a fly inside their car that they hit a telegraph pole.

And in another accident a dog jumped into a stationary car on a steep hill, dislodging the handbrake. It rolled down and hit two vehicles — both were write-offs but the dog was fine.

Another claimant had a hairy moment when he managed to knock a pot of paint over his head. He claimed for accidental damage to his Italian-made wig.

One lovestruck motorist simply claimed: “My girlfriend kissed me, I lost control and woke up in hospital.”

Another insisted : “As I turned the ignition key I glanced at my mother-in-law and headed over the embankment.”

This short-sighted client was obviously a pane. He told insurers: “I thought my window was down but found out it was up when I put my hand through it.”

A case of mistaken identity led to this case: “Coming home I drove into the wrong house and collided with a tree I don’t have.”

It’s a common problem. This driver said: “I was on the way home from the garden centre after buying some plants when a hedge sprang up obscuring my vision.”

Finally, when asked what gear they were in when their car crashed, one dozy claimant replied: “Reeboks and Wranglers.”

pages.headline: All our cash goes on pageants
pages.teaser: THE Woodall family, from Lincoln, spend their life in a whirl or hairspray and sequins
pages.articlebody:
THEIR lives are a whirl of hairspray, glitter, sequins and ribbons – yet the oldest of this family group of beauty contest hopefuls is still only 14.

In recent years five of the Woodall family’s kids — Courtney, 14, Tia, eight, Ellie, seven, Reo, three, and one-year-old Niyah — have taken Britain’s child beauty pageant scene by storm.

Together with mum Leanne, grandma Joyce, dad James and 15-year-old big brother Josh in a supporting role, the Woodalls believe they are now the UK’s largest “pageant family”.

But the hobby doesn’t come cheap — Leanne estimates that in nine months the family have spent over £5,000 on Tia alone.

And they are set to spend at least another £12,000 now that five of the kids are involved.

Every spare penny of Dad’s wage as a fork-lift truck driver funds the competitions.

Leanne, 32, says: “I love everything about pageants. I know it’s a controversial thing to get your kids involved in, but I think people read too much into it.

“Their confidence has shot through the roof since they’ve started competing. It’s wonderful watching my kids doing so well.

“There’s such a buzz about the UK scene — it’s fresh and exciting. It’s so rewarding being right at the forefront of it and I’ve never heard of as big a family as mine getting involved.”

Leanne’s obsession was sparked by seeing footage of American pageants and has escalated so much in the past 12 months that normal family life at their home in Lincoln has been put on hold.

She says: “The glitz and glamour come at a high price. You’re talking at least £500 to £600 per child per competition. There’s the entry fee plus travel expenses, costumes and grooming on top.

“The dresses alone cost £300 to £400, and you can’t wear them more than once.

“The shoes cost up to £60 a pair.

“Then there’s all the beauty, the hair, nails and tan.”

Evenings are spent searching YouTube for clips of the biggest and best pageant stars for inspiration.

Most nights after school the kids practise their choreography for the talent round and try out their hair and make-up.

Leanne says: “It’s the nature of the scene — to stay at the top, you’ve got to keep going bigger.”

Grandma Joyce, 49, a former pub landlady, is a dab hand with a needle and has made countless “one-off” outfits for the troupe.

Leanne says: “It’s so important to have good costumes. My mum is brilliant. She’s really talented at making fabulous costumes, so thankfully we don’t have to buy them all.”

Every weekend, James, 29 — who is stepdad to the two eldest kids — looks after baby Niyah, while Leanne, Joyce, Tia, Courtney and Ellie check out shops nationwide to find fabrics and accessories.

Leanne says: “Our outgoings are sky-high. James and I have cut back so much. We’ve gone from taking two holidays a year to one and when we do go away we stay in the UK.

“We don’t eat out much any more and I buy my clothes from budget stores such as Primark and Asda so I can plough money back in to the kids’ pageant wardrobe.”

The result of all their effort is a mantelpiece full of awards.

Leanne says: “The kids are all naturals, especially Tia, who won the Tiny Miss North crown in her first ever competition. All my kids have the pageant bug — even my three-year-old son.”

This year the family are going even further, as Tia prepares to become the first British competitor in the Dream Girls USA pageant in St Louis, Missouri.

Leanne says: “In Tia’s last competition, she danced to Copacabana by Barry Manilow.

“Some people think the song is inappropriate for an eight-year-old but she doesn’t understand the words. It’s just a good beat to perform to.”

Recently Leanne and Joyce have found it hard to find the sort of bold, ostentatious outfits that they say are needed to stand out.

So they plan to launch their own online pageant boutique.

Leanne says: “Mum made the showgirl costume for the Copacabana dance and it went down a storm.

“It’s really hard to find unique ‘wow-wear’ here and it’s expensive to ship it from the US.

“This is an ideal opportunity to turn something we love into a business venture. There’s the market for it and it means that we’ll stay right at the forefront of pageant fashion.”

The US pageant scene has been growing for decades and has received a lot of attention in the UK.

It was notorious US cable TV series Toddlers & Tiaras that first got full-time mum Leanne hooked.

She says: “We would watch it as a family and I’d be blown away by the glamour. Tia loved it too and was the natural leader.

“I think the other kids may have seen how much time I spent with Tia and felt a bit jealous. With six kids, there’s always rivalry.”

Only 15-year-old Josh has opted to stay out of the spotlight, though he helps by babysitting during pageant season, from March to October.

Leanne is behind all of her kids when it comes to their pageant careers, but she insists she is realistic.

She says: “We want to let them all dip their toe in and try it but I know it’s not for everyone.”

All the same, she wouldn’t want to see the kids quit on a whim — especially Tia, who has had a flush of wins.

Leanne says: “We’d never force her to do anything she didn’t want. But we’d be reluctant to let her just walk away.

“She’s so good and we’ve invested so much.

“Although it’s not all about the winning, it’s a lot of money to spend if you don’t succeed.”

Leanne dismisses the objections that are often levelled at pageants, insisting the outlandish outfits and make-up are harmless dressing up.

She adds: “Kids wear less during the summer holidays on the streets in Blackpool.

“Strangers aren’t going to walk off the street and see my kids in a swimsuit, because all the events are ticketed.

“And not every competition is full glitz. They’ve all done great in natural pageants too.”

The Woodalls intend to keep following their pageant dream for as long as they can.

Leanne says: “I am so excited waiting for pageant season to get into full swing.

“We’ll all be spending loads of time together doing what we love most.”

myView



By Dr LINDA PAPADOPOULOS, Psychologist

THE notion of little girls enjoying dressing up is nothing new and there is nothing wrong with them role-playing.

What is concerning is that in competitions such as these, they are encouraged to experiment with themes they may not be ready to deal with.

These girls are being judged on their appearance. They are aware that to succeed they not only need to act a certain way but to look a certain way.

This is an unhealthy and potentially dangerous message.

We also need to consider the impact of wearing clothes that are designed to highlight sexual characteristics they do not yet possess.

Judging girls on how they look devalues them and teaches them to base their self-worth on being appealing to others. That is simply not fair to them.

Additional reporting: Naomi Rainey

pages.teaser: THE UK’s only pet astrologer says we should be looking at our furry friends’ star signs
pages.articlebody:
MILLIONS of Brits check their own horoscopes every day – but the UK’s only pet astrologer reckons we should also be looking at our furry friends’ star signs.

Fiona Celeste, 52, believes owners can get great insights into their pets’ behaviour from their zodiac chart.

The former air stewardess says: “I know some people think I’m bonkers, but horoscopes are a great way for owners to get closer to their animals.

“You can unlock a lot about your dog or cat’s personality by looking to the horoscopes.”

Fiona, from Glasgow, has more than 100 critters on the books at her Celestial Paws business and charges £30 per pet for an “astrological interpretation”.

The mum of three, who has been providing pet horoscopes since 2009 after switching from humans, adds: "It gives me a great sense of satisfaction to bring people closer to their animals.”

Here NIKKI WATKINS and JENNY FRANCIS ask Fiona to interpret 12 pets’ personalities from their star signs – and to describe how well they “match” their owners’ signs. Then the pet owners give their verdicts.

Aries

March 21 - April 20

LONG-HAIRED chihuahua Bo-Duppy is five years old and an Aries. His owner, teaching assistant Amy Barratt-Singh, 25, from Birmingham, is a Scorpio.

Fiona says: “This confident and brave canine aims to protect and guard his family. From a young age you have been able to see early signs of his assertive, leadership potential. Sometimes this can come across to others as aggressive in style.

“He is energetic and at times may well believe that he’s in charge.

“There may be a power struggle between the signs of owner Amy and Bo-Duppy.”

Amy says: “Bo-Duppy is certainly confident and brave. He is protective to the extreme and when we are in the street he will not let a stranger come anywhere near me.

“He definitely shows leadership potential. He rules the roost in my house.”

Taurus

April 21 - May 21

LABRADOR Tumble, two, is a Taurus. He is owned by five-year-old Ben Watkins, from Tamworth, Staffs, who is a Libra.

Fiona says: “His pup tends to have a calm attitude. He adores meal times but it has to be the leanest, finest and tastiest food available.

“Watch his weight, you don’t want his beautiful appearance spoilt.

“A Libra and Taurus relationship should work very well as both signs are ruled by the planet of love.”

Ben says: “Tumble is very greedy, so we do have to watch that he doesn’t eat too much dog food, otherwise he will get fat.

“He can get a bit excitable but normally he is quite calm and lets me lie and play on him. Really he is my best friend in the whole world.”

Gemini

May 22 - June 22

DAVE is nine months old, a miniature schnauzer and is a Gemini. He lives with Taurus nail technician Zoe Pocock, 36, in Borough, South London.

Fiona says: “This canine loves accompanying you everywhere and finding out what everyone’s been up to.

“He can move like lightning, is extremely bright and adores learning new tricks. His quick mind can’t bear to be bored, so don’t leave him alone for long if you value your home. The only problem between owner and pet will be Dave does not need to eat as much as Zoe thinks he does.”

Zoe says: “Dave sleeps in his own bed and loves cuddles with his mum. He loves biting and stealing people’s slippers and shoes.”

Cancer

June 22 - July 22

BORDER terrier Dotty, eight, is a Cancer. Dental hygienist owner Alison Seymour, 47, is an Aquarius and lives in Winchester, Hants.

Fiona says: “Dotty, the Cancerian canine, probably tends to be a home-bird.

"She is sensitive, caring – and an excellent addition to the family.

“Soft and gentle on the inside but she can present a rather crusty outer shell to the world. An Aquarius owner will love observing the personality of a Cancerian pet – they will get on well.”

Alison says: “This sums Dotty up. She is very home-loving and is always a bit unsure when we’re away on holiday.”

Leo

July 23 - August 23

GERMAN shepherd Sky is two and a Leo. She lives in Shenfield, Essex, with mum-of-four Shelley Hutchins, 39, who was born on the cusp of Gemini and Taurus.

Fiona says: “This canine is loyal with a loving heart. She needs to shine and be treated like the queen she is.

“Grooming procedures will give her the feeling of being adored.

“Never ever scold, her loving heart simply couldn’t bear it.

“Things between owner and pet should work well as long as Sky gets lavished with praise.”

Shelley says: “This is very true, Sky is loving, loyal and trusting but sometimes thinks her way is the right way and doesn’t listen.”

Virgo

August 24 - September 22

BRITISH Blue cat Martha, two, is a Virgo. Her owner, Sun beauty writer Lauren Naylor, 31, lives in Wapping, East London, and is a Leo.

Fiona says: “Do make sure Martha’s bed and bowls are spotless as she’s a stickler for cleanliness. She can be a bit of a fussy eater too.

“She thrives on predictability and routine. This is why Virgo dogs really are ideal candidates for training as a helper for the disabled.

“A Virgo pet and Leo owner work well together.”

Lauren says: “This is very accurate. My dad, David, is disabled and she loves to sleep near him in his wheelchair or keep a watchful eye over him from the stairs.”

Libra

September 23 - October 23

CROSS-BREED Sophie, six, is a Libra. Owner Alexandra Newbury, 30, is a service adviser from Tamworth, Staffs and is a Capricorn.

Fiona says: “The Libra canine thrives in the company of a significant other and your relationship will be very special.

“She’s well-mannered, so you can take her anywhere.

“Balance and fairness are important to her, and she’ll expect the same high standards as you when it comes to dining and sleeping in a comfy bed.

“Owner and pet will work well together as long as they spend a lot of time together.”

Alexandra says: “That is actually freaky as it describes her so well. She expects to sleep on my bed and always wants what I’m eating for tea. She is well mannered, gentle and calm.

“You can take her anywhere. Our picture was taken in the pub where she charmed everyone.”

Scorpio

October 24 - November 22

LABRADOR Barney, three, is a Scorpio. He lives with Cancerian office worker Maggie Morgan, 42, in Hamble, Hants.

Fiona says: “The Scorpio canine tends to be suspicious by nature and terribly nosy which makes him an excellent choice as an airport sniffer dog. Your relationship is likely to be intense, as he may not be happy to share you.

“He sometimes likes to hide things so you may one day stumble upon hidden treasures that perhaps you thought were lost.

“In the stars, owner and pet are a good mix because both appreciate closeness.”

Maggie says: “On every walk, Barney has his nose to the ground, sniffing out who has been out and about on his patch.

“I’m sure he’d be an excellent sniffer dog if he’d been properly trained.

“Only he knows where he keeps his stash of my socks and gloves.”

Sagittarius

November 23 - December 21

MOGGY Forbes, four, is a Sagittarius. He is owned by Sun Woman acting deputy editor Dulcie Pearce, 30, a Virgo from West London.

Fiona says: “Forbes needs freedom to explore and create new experiences.

“He has a real thirst for adventure and would excel at expeditions.

“If he does get bored during the day, his sleeping pattern at night may become disturbed.

“Owner and pet may experience a little friction if the adventurous pet makes too much mess for his super-clean Virgo owner.”

Dulcie says: “Forbes is a true Sagittarius. His sleep patterns differ on a nightly basis and he will often be awake all night if he is bored in the day.

“He also likes nothing more than to go on an adventure – usually to stay at my parents’ house when I go on holiday.”

Capricorn

December 22 - January 20

BLACK and white puss Freddie, six, is a Capricorn and lives with Libran teacher James Burrows, 32, in Colchester, Essex.

Fiona says: “The Capricorn pet takes life very seriously. He seems wise beyond his years.

“He’ll enjoy showing you just how hard he can work and plod on until he gets it right.

“This is a good combination of pet and owner as Freddie will feel very settled.”

James says: “Freddie is a very clever cat and loves to show this off.

“He’s forever catching birds and mice, and loves to bring them to me and show me what he has achieved.”

Aquarius

January 21 - February 18

CROSS-BREED pooch Ralph, two, is an Aquarius – just like writer owner Sally Windsor, 32, of Crawley, Sussex.

Fiona says: “An Aquarian canine is special and highly intelligent. He’s a one-off, blessed with an optimistic outlook.

“He’s very interested in others and always makes them feel welcome.

“His favourite activity is to run with a pack of canine friends.

“Horoscope-wise owner and pet are a good combination.”

Sally says: “Ralph is always trying to make new friends in the park, so he’s a typical Aquarius.

“He doesn’t like sticking to the rules – a bit like me – so the two of us are always getting into trouble together.”

Pisces

February 19 - March 20

JACK Russell Porky, three, is a Pisces. Owner Alison Webster, 49, is a photographer from Kent and is a Gemini.

pages.headline: Character is all in your jeans
pages.teaser: AS STUDY shows that denim is more common than suits in the workplace, jeans expert Daniel Miller gives his verdict
pages.articlebody:
THESE new findings do not surprise me at all.

People assume that everybody wants to have strong individuality but we actually found that people strive to become ordinary.

It’s not OK to say, “When I grow up I want to be ordinary,” but actually there are real advantages to it. And jeans are ordinary.

Especially in the workplace, jeans provide a feeling of commonness. They put other people at ease and they make you feel relaxed.

There is a growing trend towards informality in the workplace. The suit is in decline and it’s being replaced with jeans.

You’re always safe with them and it’s one less thing to worry about.

In the same way that it’s useful at work, we found that it’s useful for students.

When kids go to school they don’t want to be fighting for status.

If everybody’s wearing jeans then everybody’s happy and on the same level. As part of my study I went all over the world — the Philippines, Turkey, India and Brazil.

One of the first things I did when I got to these countries was stand on a street corner and count the number of people wearing blue jeans out of the first 100.

And in most countries, around half the population wear them. And that’s kind of amazing.

When you wear jeans you become a citizen of the world.

Everyone wears them — you put babies in jeans and even the elderly — who never used to wear jeans when they were young — wear them now.

What’s interesting is that this is clearly not something that has been orchestrated by the fashion industry.

They obviously make some money out of jeans, but would make a lot more money if we bought more diverse fashionable clothes.

My co-author Sophie Woodward and I found that a lot of women will get up in the morning, try on a few outfits, take them off then put on jeans.

So when we study fashion we should probably not turn first to the catwalk but look instead at this anxiety about what to wear.

pages.headline: Fitness blitz that beats 1hour slog
pages.teaser: DOING as little as four minutes – or one 'HIT' – can be better for you than an hour’s slog. See how here
pages.articlebody:
LESS is more when it comes to working out. Doing as little as four minutes – or one “HIT” – can be better for you than an hour’s slog.

The four-minute, high-intensity training session can increase your aerobic and anaerobic capacity and speed up the metabolism, helping you burn more fat and make you look 200 per cent leaner than a traditional 60-minute aerobic workout.

Known as the closest thing we have to a fitness miracle, the HIT workout is loved by researchers and fitness pros alike for its fat-torching abilities and simplicity.

Celeb fans include Jessica Biel and Cameron Diaz.

HIT workouts are not easy, but are appealing to time-starved mums, working women and anyone juggling a hectic life.

Sun fitness expert Nicki Waterman says: “My advice is to combine your plan with 30 minutes of aerobic exercise like fast walking, jogging, swimming, cycling or dancing, for example, to get the maximum effect.

“To do a HIT, simply pick an exercise and set a timer for 20 seconds on and ten seconds rest.

“Do the exercise as hard as you possibly can for 20 seconds and then rest for ten, repeating eight to 20 times in total. And remember, you have to work to 100 per cent maximum intensity. By the end of the four minutes you should feel like you’ve done a full workout and have nothing else to give.”

Check out my favourites to get you started for one week.

But please check with your doctor before starting this exercise programme. And always warm up and cool down for at least five minutes before and after each HIT session.

MONDAY: Skipping

CARDIO and coordination all in one. Take a skipping rope and jump as fast as you can, using whichever foot pattern you like.

Options include both feet together, high knees, the “boxer shuffle” with heels in front, alternating feet, and butt-kickers.

Tip: Make sure your rope is long enough before you start – nothing ruins a good HIT workout like getting whipped across your calves.

To check for proper length, stand in the centre of your rope and pull the handles straight up. They should come at least as high as your armpits.

TUESDAY: Jumping Lunges

You already know and love (to hate?) lunges for their butt-blasting ability. Add a jump in between alternating legs to up the difficulty and cardio factor.

Start by stepping your right foot forward into a deep lunge, until your leg is parallel with the ground. Then jump, bringing your back (left) foot forward and landing in a lunge.

Tip: You can step through each lunge if jumping gets too hard.

WEDNESDAY: Box Jumps

Find a weight bench, or a step that hits somewhere between your shins and your knees.

Stand in front of it and jump on top of the bench/step with both feet together.

Jump back to the floor, again with both feet together. Try not to rest when you land and jump right back up again.

If this is too difficult, you can do step-ups onto the box instead.

THURSDAY: Mountain Climbers

Make a triangle with your hands and feet on the floor with your butt up in the air. Bring one leg towards your chest. Keeping hands on the ground, jump to switch your legs.

Tip: Just quickly touch each toe down so you’re not resting by putting whole foot down.

FRIDAY: Hindu Squats

These are similar to a traditional squat but instead of stopping when your thighs are parallel to the ground, you continue down, dropping your butt towards your heels until your fingertips brush the ground.

Going through the full range of motion gets your heart rate up faster and engages more muscles.

Tip: Don’t be afraid – contrary to popular belief, researchers now say that for healthy people, squatting to the ground won’t hurt your knees.

SATURDAY: Bicycle Sprints

Bikes are perfect for engaging your whole lower body and really getting your heart rate up for those 20 seconds.

Tip: It’s a little easier to time and to rest on a stationary bike – you can just take your feet off the pedals for ten seconds rather than trying to start and stop/coast on the road.

The HIT diet plan

SUN nutritionist Amanda Ursell says: “If your aim is to lose weight, then you need to combine your workout with a style of eating that provides energy to exercise, yet cuts empty calories that are keeping your body mass index high.

“Timing of your meals and snacks is especially important because your body needs fuel to cope with the HIT workout before you start and, once you have finished, to allow your muscles to recover and be ready for the next hard session.

“Here’s how to eat to lose weight but keep your body healthy and able to cope with the HIT plan over the coming week.”

Before you train: Whether you train before breakfast, before lunch or at the end of the day before dinner, have something like a handful of raisins, a banana or even a small smoothie an hour to 30 minutes before you start.

During training: Drink “to thirst”. This simply means have a drink when you feel the need and stop once you no longer feel thirsty.

After training: Have your meal whether it is breakfast, lunch or dinner within half an hour of finishing. If you can’t manage this, have another small snack like some dried fruit or a cereal bar.

YOUR DAILY DIET

Breakfast: This is not the week to skip breakfast, however rushed your daily schedule.

If you are training early, have breakfast once you have finished. If not, make time to have it before you leave the house.

Have a breakfast of porridge made with skimmed or semi-skimmed milk with some dried fruit such as chopped apricots; a wholegrain cereal such as Oatibix or Weetabix or a fruit salad which includes a banana with some zero per cent fat Total Greek yoghurt and a handful of sunflower seeds.

Alternatively, have two poached or boiled eggs with two pieces of toast and a glass of orange or apple juice.

Have a glass of water and your usual cup of tea or coffee using skimmed milk.

Mid-morning: Have a handful of nuts such as almonds, cashews, pistachios or Brazil nuts with an apple, orange or a pear and a glass of water.

Lunch: Build your lunch around an average-sized portion of carbohydrate foods that give you a steady supply of energy. These include pitta breads, tortilla wraps, bread, pasta, noodles, or a baked potato.

To these add some protein-rich food such as tuna, chicken, turkey, lean slices of roast beef, hard-boiled eggs, prawns, cottage or ricotta cheese, pulses such as baked beans, peas or lentils, tofu or Quorn products.

Have some veg with these such as tomato and cucumber in a sandwich, lettuce and spring onions in a wrap or pitta or salad with a baked potato and baked beans. Always have some water with your lunch.

Mid-afternoon: A couple of oat cakes with some cottage or ricotta cheese and berries; a slice of peanut butter on toast; an apple with a small matchbox-size piece of reduced-fat Cheddar or a handful of mixed nuts and raisins.

Dinner: As with lunchtime, dinner needs to be a mix of an average-size serving of carbohydrate-based foods such as new boiled potatoes, pasta, rice or noodles.

To these add some protein-rich foods such as lean red meat – lean mince, a lean pork chop or lean roast lamb; Turkey, chicken or ham; grilled, baked or canned fish; tofu, Quorn mince or “chicken” pieces, pulses such as baked beans.

Also add some vegetables. Broccoli, carrots, cauliflower, green beans, sweetcorn, tomatoes, onions – whichever you enjoy and find easy to prepare.

pages.headline: No secret to being a sex symbol
pages.teaser: HOLLYWOOD siren and Transformers star MEGAN FOX on family, fame and films
pages.articlebody:
MEGAN FOX has become one of the world’s hottest sex symbols, thanks to hit movies such as Transformers and Jennifer’s Body.

She will next be seen – playing herself – in Sacha Baron Cohen’s latest film, The Dictator, released on May 11.

Megan, 25, married her long-term boyfriend, 38-year-old actor Brian Austin Green, in 2010 and there are now reports she is pregnant.

Here she speaks to GARTH PEARCE about what her mother taught her.

MY mum Darlene taught me to fight for what I believe. She was strict, but wanted a daughter who could look after herself.

I was not the easiest of girls to bring up. From very young I seemed to know what I wanted to do in life — singing, dancing, acting.

It meant my mum had to drive for miles to take me to various classes. She was always encouraging about self-improvement.

She took me to auditions in Los Angeles, which was on the other side of the country from where we lived in Florida.

I was born in Oak Ridge, a small town in Tennessee, but was brought up mostly in St Petersburg, Florida, after my mother remarried.

When she and Dad were together, they did not have much money. But I was happy as a kid.

It made me realise you don’t have to be rich to be happy. My dad used to hunt ducks and my mum would put them in the pot. We lived modestly.

My mum says I was born really ballsy. She’s put up with it very well.

I attended a Pentecostal church and then a Christian school. I had to obey strict rules at school and at home. I was grounded a lot.

I got a diploma from a correspondence programme. It was the deal I made with my mum. I had to have a real diploma before she would allow me to drop out of Christian school and move to Los Angeles.

There have been some struggles along the way, which my mum has seen me through. I am also not the easiest of people to be friends with.

I think it is my fault. I work away from home and have learned to be on my own.

I don’t socialise much on a film set and don’t have to become best friends with the people I work with.

There is a saying in Hollywood that what happens on a film set stays on a film set. But if I’d ever dated a co-star, it would have been downright depressing. Most actors would not appeal to most women, if they actually met them.

I met Brian when I was 18. I was too young to remember his show, Beverly Hills 90210, so I didn’t know who he was. But I knew I was instantly in love.

There is no secret to being a sex symbol. I play the game, that’s all.

If people want to think of me as wild and crazy, that’s up to them. The fact is, I’ve only had two serious boyfriends in my life — and I married one.

I have the same hang-ups as any other girl. Am I too fat? Too thin? Do I wear the right clothes? You think about it so much, it can hurt how you live.

So am I insecure? God, yes. Show me a woman who says she’s totally secure about everything in her life and I will show you a pain in the ass.

There have been some bad moments along the way, during which calls to my mum have meant a lot.

I lived in New York, doing TV comedy Hope & Faith, and it was cold and miserable.

I was either at work or home in a little apartment, on my own. I let whole days slip by, doing nothing.

I am confident in how I project myself but not in terms of how I look. It all came to a head when I was making 2008 film How To Lose Friends And Alienate People in London.

There was one scene in which I danced around in lingerie. I suddenly felt like I couldn’t do the scene and asked if I could wear a skirt.

The director, quite rightly, said it would look ridiculous.

But I was not happy. It ended up with the producer serving me a beer before the scene. I was tired from working non-stop on several films, was suffering from jet lag on the trip to England and started to worry about my ability.

That’s where Mum comes in. I called her a few times from London and she was able to calm me down and encourage me.

I am still her little girl, whatever way you want to look at it.

Beyonce

Style secret: Lots of flash or expensive gear can mask a deeper insecurity that makes the wearer feel a need to prove themself.

Holly Willoughby

Style secret: The girl next door may secretly wish to be more assertive and outgoing. Often more complicated than she appears.

Italian duo Roma and Fiorentina are on red alert, while Turkish outfit Galatasaray are another team monitoring him.

Former club Feyenoord would also love to take him back if they are not priced out.

Argy ace Maxi is also being told he can leave, as Kop boss Kenny Dalglish looks to bring in younger talent.

Maxi, 31, also has 12 months left on his contract but has made just 15 appearances this season.

City’s record signing also repeated his desire to stay at the Etihad despite fresh rumours linking him with Real Madrid.

ALEX FERGUSON believes Manchester United’s title-winning pedigree has helped them leave their rivals trailing in recent weeks.

The champions opened up a five-point lead over Manchester City this week — and it could be eight by 4pm on Easter Sunday.

And while City have shown signs of cracking, United have taken everything in their stride.

The City squad have plenty of experience but are short of players who have gone the distance in England’s top flight.

In contrast, Fergie’s squad have plenty of Premier League winners’ medals between them. And the boss said: “It’s down to experience. It never fazes them and they can handle it.

“Paul Scholes and Ryan Giggs are unparalleled of course, but Wayne Rooney has four title medals, Rio Ferdinand has five.

“Michael Carrick has got a few and even people like Rafael have got two or three.

“So it all adds to the experience — and that’s valuable at this time of the season.”

United’s away form has also been a major factor. City have stuttered on their travels with a paltry two wins — and five goals — from their last nine. United have won 10 of their last 12 away. Fergie added: “Last season, we were fortunate as we had a great home record and only dropped two points at Old Trafford. But that was balanced out by the away form.

“This season, we’ve picked up fewer points at home but away form has been much better.

“We’ve had the most clean sheets away in the league this season and you need that.”

Fergie is growing frustrated with Paul Pogba’s refusal to sign a new deal. City and Juventus are monitoring the situation with the 19-year-old midfielder.

pages.articlebody:
ROBERTO MANCINI has told his Manchester City team they must win all seven of their remaining games to stay in the title hunt.

The moneybags outfit dropped seven of the last 12 available points to surrender the initiative to bitter rivals Manchester United.

By the time City kick off against Arsenal on Sunday, they could find themselves eight points behind the champions.

Boss Mancini admitted last weekend that would probably be too many — although he still feels 92 points would be enough to win the title.

City can still do that if they win each of their remaining fixtures, including the derby with United at the Etihad on April 30.

Mancini said: “After the Sunderland game I said only, ‘Believe in yourselves’ to my players because we have seven games — 21 points.

“I think with 92 points we will win the title. It is important we arrive in the derby one or two points behind or maybe above them.

“This could be difficult because I don’t know if they can lose six points but it is important we believe in this.”

City fans are starting to fear their title dream is over after leading the way for so long. But Mancini has urged them to stick with the team and see if they can yet claw back Alex Ferguson’s men.

The Italian said: “We should be strong, I think, always. The message for the fans is always the same: We will do everything to win this title.

“Maybe in this moment we can think it is difficult — but it can be enough to do some better results than United.”

Winger Adam Johnson says there are no plans for City to throw in the towel with five weeks of the campaign still remaining.

He said: “There’s been a lot of talk about the title race and who will come out on top but there are still seven games to be played.

“It’s true we are relying on other teams to some extent but they have still got to come to our place and have some tricky games left.

“We’ll be focused and ready for Arsenal at the weekend and we’ll keep trying to win games and see where that takes us.”

pages.subdeck: BROTHERS IN ARMS ... Lionel Messi and Andres Iniesta
pages.headline: We'll Mess Blue up!
pages.teaser: SPANISH midfielder has vowed to come back and haunt Chelsea in semi-finals
pages.articlebody:
ANDRES INIESTA has vowed to come back and haunt Chelsea.

And the Barcelona midfield genius warned Blues boss Roberto Di Matteo: Record-breaker Leo Messi is out to get you.

Iniesta’s late strike took Barca to the final at Chelsea’s expense on a controversial night in 2009 when ref Tom Henning Ovrebo turned down FOUR Blues penalty claims.

His clincher also killed off AC Milan on Tuesday night to set up a semi-final with Chelsea. And the man who scored Spain’s World Cup final winner against Holland in 2010 still has a thirst for glory.

He said: “I have a big appetite to play semi-finals. I have a feeling I should score more goals than I do.

“It’s a question of ambition as I try to help the team in every game and scoring makes a player more complete. This team always responds on the big occasions.

“Our success is the fruit of our hard work, year in year out, and it’s the only lesson you can learn.

“Our team maintains the ambition and the results are the natural consequence of that.”

Argentine Messi set a new single season Champions League record with his two spot-kicks in the 3-1 win over Milan — and now has 14 goals in the competition this term.

This came two weeks after he broke Barca’s all-time scoring record as a La Liga hat-trick against Granada took him to 233 goals in total.

Messi will be itching to keep the run going against Chelsea and lead Barcelona to the final in Munich.

Iniesta said: “Leo will pulverise every record there is. From our side we will do our best to help him break as many as possible.”

Former Liverpool star Javier Mascherano said: “We want to get to our third final in four years.

“It would be brilliant. Everyone here wants to be the first team to defend the Champions League.”

Barca full-back Daniel Alves pinpoints going through on aggregate on that 2009 night at Stamford Bridge as the springboard for everything the Catalan giants have gone on to achieve.

He said: “It’s the goal that led us to the final and thanks to that goal we went all the way and won this title. This goal gave us confidence and faith in what we were doing.

“It formed the basis of our success in our quest to win trophies.”

Putting Chelsea out came in coach Pep Guardiola’s first season and his side went on to complete a treble of Champions League, La Liga and Copa Del Rey.

In all, since that fateful night at the Bridge, Barca have won 13 out of 16 trophies they have competed for — three La Ligas, two Champions Leagues, two Club World Cups, two European Super Cups, three Spanish Super Cups and one Spanish Cup.

Alves said: “We strive to make our fans happy for the way we play, for the way we compete, for the love we have for the game.”

Victory over Milan put Barca into the semis for a fifth straight time.

Alves added: “We want to defend our title but we know it’s difficult.

“We are not invincible. When we are at our level, it’s extremely difficult to beat us but I’m not saying it is impossible.”

pages.subdeck: RAUL OVER ... Goalscorer Raul Meireles celebrates
pages.headline: Chelsea 2 Benfica 1
pages.teaser: RAUL MEIRELES smashed a late winner to set up mouth-watering semi with Barcelona
pages.articlebody:
BENFICA might have Jesus for a manager but it is Roberto Di Matteo who is working the miracles right now.

Chelsea’s interim manager has turned whine into champagne by leading the club to their sixth Champions League semi-final in nine years.

And even the prospect of facing the might of Barcelona in the last four cannot put a dampener on the renewed sense of optimism coursing through Stamford Bridge.

Frank Lampard’s first-half penalty and a stoppage-time thunderbolt from Raul Meireles were just about enough to finish off the Eagles of Lisbon — and their histrionic manager Jorge Jesus.

Now the real work begins for Di Matteo as he tries to figure out a way to stop Lionel Messi and his chums in two weeks’ time.

It is hard to believe that it was just one month ago that Di Matteo was thrown in at the deep end following the sacking of Andre Villas-Boas.

But in that time he has totally transformed a team that was heading nowhere fast until Roman Abramovich opened the trapdoor under AVB.

This was Chelsea’s seventh win in nine under Di Matteo’s stewardship after he reminded the club’s superstars just what they are capable of.

They might have made hard work of seeing off a Benfica team reduced to 10 men for the final 50 minutes of last night’s match.

And Barcelona probably will not be quaking in their boots at having to face England’s last surviving European representatives, especially as John Terry was substituted on the hour amid fears he has cracked two ribs.

But only a fool would write off Chelsea’s chances now they are back in their comfort zone and starting to believe that this just could be their year to conquer Europe at last.

Chelsea might have thought they had done the hard work when they won 1-0 in Lisbon last week. But those illusions were quickly shattered by a Benfica team who clearly believed this tie was very much alive.

The Portuguese giants arrived at Stamford Bridge determined to snatch an early away goal to cancel out Chelsea’s first-leg advantage.

And they might have claimed it but for Lampard’s crucial block to keep out Axel Witsel’s shot from the edge of the area.

Even though Benfica had been handicapped by the absence of a single fit centre-half, Chelsea were finding it difficult to break out of their own half to test their visitors’ defensive problems.

Unfortunately for Benfica, when Chelsea did get at stand-in stopper Javi Garcia, the Spaniard’s limitations were ruthlessly exposed.

Terry’s long ball was allowed to bounce in the box and, as Ashley Cole moved in to make his challenge, he was barged over by Garcia.

Slovenian ref Damir Skomina pointed immediately to the spot and though goalkeeper Artur got a strong hand to Lampard’s 21st-minute penalty, it was not enough to keep the ball out of his net.

Chelsea now had the breathing space they required yet were still not out of the woods as Terry was forced to clear off his line from Oscar Cardozo.

They were hardly helped by their inability to keep the ball and a dangerous habit of conceding free-kicks in their half, shortcomings which will need to be addressed before Barcelona come calling in two weeks’ time.

But any thoughts of a Benfica comeback were torpedoed with the dismissal of right-back Maxi Pereira five minutes before half-time.

The Uruguayan defender had already been booked for disputing Chelsea’s penalty when he caught John Obi Mikel with a careless lunge which was met with a second yellow card from ref Skomina.

Yet still Benfica refused to accept their fate as Cardozo tested the reflexes of Petr Cech shortly after the break.

Chelsea’s numerical advantage, though, was beginning to take its toll and Salomon Kalou almost added to his first-leg goal when his shot struck the far post.

Fernando Torres had a low effort deflected wide by Garcia and then failed to hit the target with a volley after Artur could only parry Juan Mata’s fierce shot.

Kalou was next to be denied by the Benfica keeper and he then fired narrowly wide after swivelling on to Cole’s inviting low cross into the danger area.

Di Matteo was becoming increasingly frustrated by his team’s failure to put this tie beyond doubt.

And his concerns were confirmed in the 85th minute when Benfica grabbed the goal that left Chelsea clinging on for dear life.

Cech had already defied gravity to claw away a goal-bound header from substitute Yannick Djalo.

But David Luiz lost Garcia at the resultant corner, leaving the Spaniard unchallenged to glance home a header. Suddenly Chelsea were just one goal away from blowing it and snatching defeat from the jaws of victory.

But with Benfica throwing everyone forward for one last hurrah, substitute Meireles nicked the ball off the head of Witsel and raced half the length of the pitch before unleashing an unstoppable shot beyond keeper Artur.

Game over, Benfica. Game on, Barcelona.

pages.subdeck: GRIN 'N BEAR IT ... Darren Bent puts one good foot up on his road to recovery
pages.headline: My problems do not really matter
pages.teaser: CROCKED England and Villa striker Darren Bent is refusing to feel sorry for himself
pages.articlebody:
DARREN BENT has good reason to feel sorry for himself.

The Aston Villa and England striker is out for the rest of the season which surely means he will miss Euro 2012, too.

And after being left behind for the World Cup in South Africa two years ago, that must be tough for him to take.

But Bent is not praying every day for his own speedy return after ankle surgery.

He is pleading for Bolton’s Fabrice Muamba and Villa team-mate Stiliyan Petrov to make miraculous recoveries.

Bent, 28, said: “It certainly puts everything into perspective for me.

“I’m sitting here worrying if I’m going to be back playing again in eight weeks’ time while Stan and Fabrice are fighting for their lives.

“How can I get all beat up about my problems when those guys are fighting tooth and nail to survive?

“That’s why I’m praying every day they are on the mend again very soon.”

Bent has been so impressed by the way both the stricken stars have faced up to their personal battles.

And he has been uplifted by the reaction of fans everywhere since Muamba suffered a cardiac arrest at White Hart Lane last month and then to the news last week that Petrov has acute leukaemia.

Bent added: “It has really surprised me but it’s fantastic.

“We are all so used to football fans being criticised. But so many have come together and are supporting the two lads.

“Basically they are saying ‘We are all in it together’ — and that’s every football team, not just here but around the world.

“We have seen Barcelona players wearing Fabrice T-shirts and Chelsea players wearing ‘Get well Stan’ tops.

“I must admit it’s all brought a lump to my throat.”

Only after talking at length about the plight of his fellow pros will Bent address his own 10-week fight for fitness after damaging ankle ligaments at Wigan on February 25.

The striker admitted: “It’s frustrating big-time. It’s the first serious injury of my career and the timing could not be worse. We are coming to crunch time in the season and Villa are fighting for survival.

“Of course I want to be out there helping but it doesn’t look like I’ll play again this season.

“That means I’ll probably be missing the Euros too, so it’s a big blow.

“The time-frame for the injury takes me to May 16 by which time the ankle will be fully healed and my rehab completed.”

That is 10 days before England’s first Euro warm-up game, in Oslo against Norway. And Bent wants to be there.

He added: “I’d just say to the new England manager, whoever it is, give me a chance.

“Then it will be down to whether he does take a chance on me, at least in one of the warm-ups.”

But what if the new Three Lions boss is Harry Redknapp?

The manager who infamously said “his missus” could have scored a chance Bent missed for Spurs against Portsmouth in 2009. That cruel barb has dogged the striker ever since — but Bent is a forgiving soul.

He said: “If Harry gets the job then good on him.

“Hopefully if I can get back from injury in time he will pick me.

“I know people still talk about what he said even now. But I’m not annoyed about it any more.

“I’ve lost count of how many goals I’ve scored since then — I think I scored two against Bolton the very next week.

“That’s Harry and he can say what he wants, and managers do make off-the-cuff remarks. But that is one everyone remembers.

“You have to take it and move on. It doesn’t bother me now although it bothered me probably more than it should have done at the time. My attitude now is if you score enough goals, that’s the best answer to any criticism.”

And Bent has a back-up plan if the Euros do come too soon for him.

He said: “If Euro 2012 doesn’t happen for me I’m definitely up for playing in the Olympic Games.

“It’s a massive event and it doesn’t come to your home town but once in a lifetime. It would be ridiculous to give up the opportunity.”

Don’t dismiss the notion. Bent is working hard to be ready, revealing: “These days I am getting around a lot better — I’ve even had the boot off a couple of times.

“I’m doing lots of swimming and I’m getting pretty quick. So if I don’t make the GB football team maybe I can make the swimming team and take on Michael Phelps.”

And I bet ’Arry’s missus couldn’t do that.

pages.headline: Can Chelsea really beat Barca?
pages.teaser: SUNSPORT gives its verdict on whether the Blues can handle the Nou Camp aces
pages.articlebody:
Defence

JOHN TERRY is too slow and David Luiz likes time on the ball — two certain recipes for a defensive disaster against Lionel Messi and Co.

The Blues backline will not be found wanting for the fundamental attributes such as desire and determination, but when it comes to class and technique, it is difficult to see them keeping out the European champions.

Messi’s five against Bayer Leverkusen was a stand-out, although the whole team look capable of scoring.

VERDICT: NO

Midfield

THE middle of the park is where many believe this semi-final will be decided. But Chelsea had better hope not!

Not only will the Blues midfield have to keep pressing, they will also have to avoid being pressed. And on last night’s evidence it is difficult to see them doing either. How can the Bridge midfield overpower the maestros of Barcelona when they failed to dominate Benfica?

But the task is clear — they cannot let Iniesta and his mates dominate the match.

VERDICT: NO

Attack

AN on-song Didier Drogba, full of hustle bustle and deadly intent, might be able to cause Barca’s defence a few problems with his physical presence.

But you can’t imagine the likes of Pique, Puyol and Mascherano having many sleepless nights over the thought of dealing with Fernando Torres — unless it is laughter responsible for keeping them awake.

Orchestrating a threat will give Roberto di Matteo one of his biggest tactical headaches since taking over at the Bridge.

VERDICT: NO

Tactics

CHELSEA played the first 20 minutes last night on the counter and that is something they will not be able to do against Barcelona — or else they will get mullered.

Right from the off, they will need to press Barca toe-to-toe and it’s hard to know whether they have got that in them.

Their best hope is getting another referee like Damir Skomina, who will always be welcomed back to the Bridge for red-carpet treatment after last night’s display.

pages.subdeck: BRING ON BARCA ... Roberto Di Matteo faces an almighty challenge in the semi-final
pages.headline: Now RDM needs summit special
pages.teaser: STEVEN HOWARD on the task facing Chelsea in the Champions League semi-final
pages.articlebody:
AND now the road starts to get considerably steeper.

A one-in-one incline, in fact, with Chelsea staring up at the North face of the Eiger.

Yes, in the end they just about held off Benfica’s challenge at Stamford Bridge. And they have to be applauded for the way they have bounced back under Roberto Di Matteo.

But it was again a night that exposed the weaknesses in the English game against teams with superior technique, an ability to retain the ball and pace.

The same weaknesses that had already accounted for both Manchester clubs and Arsenal.

And now it’s Barcelona, the team that patented modern-day ball retention. Along with pace and technique.

Should Chelsea defend like they did in a desperate final 30 minutes last night they will be taken apart by the best team in the world boasting, in Lionel Messi, the best player in the world and a man already with 58 goals this season.

And, behind him, wonderful players such as Xavi, Iniesta, Fabregas, Pedro, Dani Alves, Pique and Puyol. And all the rest. A side that, in beating Milan 24 hours before Chelsea scraped past Benfica, had reached a fifth successive semi-final, a figure matched only by the Real Madrid of Di Stefano and Puskas in the Fifties.

After that — well, is there an after that? Should there be, by some miracle, it hardly gets much easier.

Either Jose Mourinho’s La Liga leaders Real Madrid or Bayern Munich, Franck Ribery and Chelsea old boy Arjen Robben in their own Allianz Arena.

Pick the bones out of that.

Cruising at one point last night, Chelsea fell apart once John Terry went off on the hour. Suddenly tentative and unsure, they were run off their feet as Benfica poured down the flanks and into the box.

And this by a team reduced to 10 men after 40 minutes.

And with a makeshift defence after first-choice central defenders Luisao and Jardel were left nursing injuries back home in Lisbon.

And with most of the questions being posed by substitutes Yannick Djalo, Nelson Oliveira and Rodrigo.

If 10 men — including three subs — can reduce Chelsea to such a state of panic what sort of damage can 11 from Barcelona inflict? Especially down the flanks where Alves must be already licking his lips at the prospect of getting at the Chelsea back four.

Another of Chelsea’s problems in the final 30 minutes was a glaring inability to control either the ball or the game in midfield.

If they don’t get it right from the start against Barca, the Xavi-Iniesta-Messi axis will have Frank Lampard and Co chasing shadows.

Chelsea also cannot afford to squander the sort of chances that fell to Salomon Kalou (twice) and Fernando Torres after the break.

With the buffer of a 20th-minute Lampard penalty, Chelsea should have been strolling. But, with Terry off, they were exposed and had it not been for Petr Cech and some poor finishing of their own, Benfica would have equalised long before they did.

When they did get the goal they deserved it was due to poor defending by David Luiz and substitute Gary Cahill — both lost by Javi Garcia as he rose to head home. Benfica then might even have won it through Oliveira.

And, yet, where there’s life there’s hope. Certainly, Chelsea deserve a lot of credit for their unlikely revival under Di Matteo, a run that has seen just one defeat in nine games.

England’s lone European standard-bearers could hardly have done more at Stamford Bridge in the Champions League. All five games won including the heroic 4-1 dismantling of Napoli after the Italians had established a two-goal lead from the first leg.

And yet. And yet. Despite that home form, you worry what might happen in a fortnight’s time when Barcelona come calling. But Barca coach Pep Guardiola will not underestimate Chelsea. On Tuesday he said: “Chelsea may have had problems but their great players are coming good at the right time. It is a team with enormous experience.”

And, yes, that experience showed last night as they withstood both early pressure and Benfica intimidation to take the sting out of their opponents.

Nerves seemed to have been settled in the 21st minute when Garcia, one of the replacement centre-halves, bundled Ashley Cole over in the box and Lampard drilled his spot-kick under Artur. Then Maxi Pereira, already booked for moaning about the penalty, was sent off after receiving a second yellow for a foul on Jon Obi Mikel just before half-time.

Though Branislav Ivanovic had had to clear off the line, the tie appeared to be swinging Chelsea’s way.

But those misses by Kalou and Torres gave Benfica the reprieve they needed in which to mount that furious late assault. Chelsea were all over the place. Yes, Meireles scored a miraculous injury-time winner but Chelsea were far from convincing.

And now it’s Barcelona.

pages.headline: Big Sam: You're talking b******s!
pages.teaser: HAMMERS boss last night stepped up his war with West Ham supporters
pages.articlebody:
SAM ALLARDYCE last night stepped up his war with West Ham fans by telling them: ‘You’re talking b******s.’

It was the manager’s latest salvo after he branded supporters ‘deluded’ over their criticism of his tactics.

And big Sam admitted he could face the chop if he does not win promotion.

That was despite vice-chairman Karren Brady’s assurance that his job will be safe if the Hammers fail to go up.

Allardyce, whose side are four points off second place, said: “Negativity has been very much in the forefront recently, which is strange because we have lost one in 12.

“You get opinions about our results like ‘James Tomkins shouldn’t be playing in midfield because he is a centre-half.’

“You get all that b******s. What happens is I look at the performance of every player and say to everyone who says that: ‘You’re talking b******s.’

“He played in that holding role for three games when we had 10 men — so that is how short memories are. That is how much b******s is talked in football.

“I don’t listen to that drivel because what bothers me is that James Tomkins plays well.”

West Ham have slipped from top to third in six weeks and a major factor has been poor home form.

They lost 4-2 to promotion rivals Reading on Saturday to end a run of five draws at Upton Park.

But West Ham are better away than at home, and Allardyce is desperate for a win at Barnsley tomorrow.

pages.headline: Swann salutes skipper Strauss
pages.teaser: ANDREW STRAUSS made his highest Test score for eight months — and was then described by Graeme Swann as the ‘best captain in world cricket’
pages.articlebody:
ANDREW STRAUSS made his highest Test score for eight months — and was then described by Graeme Swann as the ‘best captain in world cricket’.

Strauss recaptured some of his run-making form with a solid, mentally-tough innings of 61 on day two of the Second Test.

It will help reduce the scrutiny on his leadership, especially if England go on to complete the victory against Sri Lanka they need to retain the world No 1 status.

But Strauss will still feel it was a job only half done because he failed to progress to that elusive century. He now has just one 100 in his last 49 Test innings.

At least he had the thrill of raising his bat for a milestone and, importantly for his team, laid the foundation for a big total.

Strauss, 35, and Alastair Cook, 27, put on 122 for the first wicket and the visitors reached 154-1 after bowling out Sri Lanka for 275.

Cook is short of runs himself and so his watchful vigil was also a big relief.

Spin bowler Swann, who took four wickets in the first innings, insisted: “Everyone is rooting for Straussy because he has come under a lot of very unfair criticism.

“He’ll be kicking himself not to have gone on after scoring 50 but he provided a very solid start for us.

“He hasn’t shown any signs of pressure. It’s obvious there’s been a bit of a witch-hunt towards him recently.

“I think it’s unjustified but you wouldn’t tell from the way he carries himself and the way he talks and captains the side. He’s a very laid-back, phlegmatic character. I’m his strongest advocate, you’ll get nothing but support from me.

“He’s the best captain in world cricket and a world-class opening bat. He should be afforded some leeway because of what he’s achieved.

“He’s not in horrible nick, he’s not scratching around.

“His barren spell is a lot better than other people’s barren spells and he’ll be scoring hundreds again before you know it.”

Strauss’ ability to produce an important innings under pressure showed his mental fortitude. He should skipper the First Test against West Indies at Lord’s on May 17, regardless of what happens here — although a win will help silence any speculation.

He was eventually caught behind aiming a cut shot at Tillakaratne Dilshan.

Cook went on to 77 not out and England will attempt to bat throughout today and allow the pitch to deteriorate.

England took the final four Sri Lanka wickets for the addition of 37 runs. Swann said: “That was probably our most complete day of the winter.”

SUNPORT journo TIM HEMING is on a mission to put the Pride back into a few readers - with a FREE pint of ale.

Here he explains how he’ll be forking out for his biggest-ever round - having already finished a marathon session:

“PRIDE comes before a fall - but not if I run into a traffic cone at the 12-mile mark like last year.

No idea what I’m on about?

On April 22 the London Marathon shuts down the Capital for a day as almost 40,000 runners plod through the streets - and I’ll be one of them.

It is the biggest one-day annual fundraising event in the world and like the vast majority of those bob-a-joggers out there, I’m cap in hand for a few pennies.

Problem is, like Quasimodo or a naff X Factor contestant, I just don’t have a good enough back story to really tug on the heartstrings.

Instead, I’m pledging that anyone who sponsors me - be it tuppence or two hundred quid - will be plied with a FREE PINT of the dedicated race ale, London Pride.

A simple premise but a quick-fire social media experiment to bump up the funds for outstanding cancer charities The Jane Tomlinson Appeal and CLIC Sargent (for children with cancer).

There is plenty more information about the charities on the sponsor page or their individual websites.

To claim your free London Pride, just:

1. Visit the sponsor page at uk.virginmoneygiving.com/timheming

2. Email tim.heming@the-sun.co.uk with your name and address to tell me you have done it.

3. Tweet this page, Facebook 'Like' it (both above), or send the link on to your mates.

If enough of you pitch in, I could be pounding the streets permanently - bankrupt and homeless - but at least I won’t be a helpless young child with a failing body riddled with cancer.

Thankfully, a pint of London Pride doesn’t sit quite as heavily as the last sentence.

That’s my last orders for now. Cheers for reading.

And if it’s your first or 100th marathon on April 22, or if you are coming along to enjoy the festival atmosphere - or even claim the free pint at the finish line - enjoy the day."

pages.subdeck: M PEOPLE ... Phil Mickelson and Rory McIlroy at last year's US Open
pages.headline: He’s gonna Ror again ‘n again
pages.teaser: AMERICAN star expects McIlroy to join him as a multiple-Masters winners
pages.articlebody:
PHIL MICKELSON is tipping Rory McIlroy to join him as a multiple-Masters champion.

Mickelson is aiming to match Tiger Woods’ haul of four Augusta triumphs this week but believes McIlroy is very much the future of The Masters.

He said: “I think Rory will continue his great play and as he learns the subtleties of this course I think he’s going to win here a number of times.

“I think he’s an incredible talent. You could tell when he first came out here on Tour he was going to be an incredible golfer.

“Like everybody else I can see his talent and ability. He plays without fear, which is a great way to play.

“When you get soft conditions like we have this week — and which we had at the US Open last June — he’s going to light it up.”

McIlroy relished conditions at Congressional as he romped to an eight-shot victory barely two months after his final-round collapse at Augusta.

He set a new record for the lowest score in any US Open, 268, and his 16-under total was another new best.

It was hard to believe he had been labelled a choker for shooting 80 in that final round of the Masters, after teeing off with a four-shot lead.

That included an horrendous 43 on the back nine, launched by a triple bogey on the 10th.

Fast forward a year and everyone is describing this Masters as a match-up between McIlroy and Woods, who comes into this event after a victory at Bay Hill, his first US Tour win since 2009.

Luke Donald and Lee Westwood disagree but Mickelson grinned: “I’m cool with it. I don’t have a problem. I am where I am and I’m fine with it.”

Another multiple Major champion, Ernie Els, is far from convinced golf is about to be dominated by a Rory-Tiger era.

Els, winner of two US Opens as well as lifting the Claret Jug in 2002, also doubts Woods will overhaul Jack Nicklaus’ haul of 18 Majors, having been stuck on 14 since 2008.

Els said: “Over the years I’ve been such a supporter of Tiger, even though he’s beaten my ass so many times. But I’d say no.

“I’m still a fan of his but he doesn’t have that momentum any more. And I know what that’s like. It’s tough to keep working your way back, reinventing your swing and getting over all your injuries.

“He’ll probably win another two Majors but I don’t think he’ll break Jack’s record.”

McIlroy was also quick to shoot down the theory this Masters is a two-horse race.

He said: “You have to remember, there’s 80-plus players in this field. It’s not just about two guys or three guys or whatever.

“It’s nice to be getting all this praise and everything, but you have to take it with a pinch of salt.

“I’m nowhere near the level Tiger reached. I definitely don’t have the achievements he has, or anything like the amount of success that he’s had over the last 15 years.

“Hopefully I can one day even get close to that point. But for now I’m just happy to be here and hopefully have a good chance of winning.

“Mentally, I feel like if I get myself in a winning position again, I’ll be able to approach it a lot better. I felt like I didn’t approach it well at all last year.

“It was out of character for me, and I now realise I just needed to try and be myself a little bit more.

“For me, it was trying to be too focused, too perfect. Now I feel like myself, I need to be more relaxed.

“I sort of naturally have a bounce in my step. Last year I was staring at the ground trying to shut everything out, and I looked hunched and insular. I won’t make that mistake again.”

pages.subdeck: BAG MEN ... Ant and Dec caddied for Lee Westwood yesterday
pages.headline: Come in lucky 53
pages.teaser: FATE could decide if Lee Westwood’s agonising wait for a first Major comes to an end
pages.articlebody:
FATE could decide if Lee Westwood’s agonising wait for a first Major comes to an end at this week’s Masters.

Westwood has five top-three finishes in the last 10 Majors.

And he will slip on a Green Jacket on Sunday if an incredible tale of coincidence continues.

The last three Masters tournaments to finish on Easter Sunday have been won by players whose caddies were wearing No 53 on Augusta’s trademark white boiler suits.

And Westy’s bagman Billy Foster has 53 on his chest this week.

Angel Cabrera was the most recent Easter champ in 2009, following in the footsteps of 2007 winner Zach Johnson and 2004 champion Phil Mickelson.

Foster was amazed and delighted when I pointed out the bizarre coincidence.

He said: “I didn’t have a clue that this was such a lucky number — we’d better do our best to keep the sequence going then!

“We all know Lee’s got the game to do it from the way he played two years ago when he was runner-up to Phil.

“Lee played the course beautifully and his score would have been good enough to win The Masters in most years. We just came up against someone playing out of his skin.

“Lee’s hitting the ball lovely at the moment so you’ve got to give him a big chance. If fate decided to lend a helping hand that would be nice.

“I’m not particularly superstitious and neither is Lee. But that could change if he slips on the Green Jacket on Sunday.”

Foster, 46, is one of the most respected caddies in the game and has carried the bags of some of the greats — including Seve Ballesteros, Darren Clarke and Sergio Garcia.

And he even caddied for Tiger Woods at a Presidents Cup when Steve Williams was injured.

He added: “I’ve caddied for a couple of Major winners in Seve and Darren, but not when they won their Majors.

“It’s been a long wait. I’ve been caddying for 30 years now and it’s about time I saw my man win one of the big ones. I’d be thrilled if Lee did it here. He’s been knocking on the door for so long that it’s got to open for him soon.”

Westwood, who had Ant ’n Dec as his caddies for yesterday’s par-3 competition, finished on 13-under two years ago — a total that would have won the previous eight Masters.

He shot sub-par rounds all four days but came up against an inspired Mickelson, who hit back-to-back 67s over the weekend to beat him by three shots.

Westy, 38, said: “I look back on that as a positive as it proved I can play this course well and break par when the heat’s really on.

“It was just a case of Phil playing unbelievable golf. I’ve been close in so many Majors now. I’m sure my time will come.”

WESTWOOD'S KILLER HOLES

HERE’S the hole truth — LEE WESTWOOD gives you the exclusive lowdown on the holes that could make or break his bid to go one better than his 2010 second-place finish at Augusta.

HOLE 7

THIS is such a difficult fairway to hit. Fifteen years ago there was a safe way to play this hole — hit a three-iron off the tee and then a wedge. But it has been lengthened so much there’s no alternative but to use a driver. I hit driver and wedge in practice. Let’s hope I can do that in competition.

HOLE 11

THE start of Amen Corner is a very long hole now. It plays its full 505 yards, particularly when the fairways are soft and there’s no run on the ball. The approach is tough because of the water on the left of the green. It only takes a slight pull to be wet. This is a take-the-par-and-run sort of hole.

HOLE 14

IT’S a tricky drive that you just have to sling up there as far as you can. If you get it on the fairway it’s a birdie chance – but if you miss in the wrong spot you’re knackered. I’m talking three yards difference between it being fine and impossible.
